content.text: Let me look for the contribution guide which likely contains the style guide:

content.content:
1→.. Copyright © 2023, Amazon, LLC.
     2→
     3→   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
     4→
     5→   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
     6→   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html
     7→
     8→   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
     9→   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
    10→
    11→
    12→##################
    13→Contribution guide
    14→##################
    15→
    16→.. meta::
    17→   :description: Contribution guide for the Golden Path family of tooling
    18→   :keywords: bones, native aws, naws, contribution, contributing
    19→
    20→.. contents::
    21→   :local:
    22→
    23→Thanks for your interest in contributing to the |team-nade|’s services, tooling, libraries, and
    24→templates!
    25→
    26→.. _contributing-start:
    27→
    28→Getting started
    29→===============
    30→
    31→For tracking purposes, :simt:`open an issue for our team <create/templates/aff28c08-a586-4456-b301-6c3d4e05230d>`.
    32→
    33→The |team-nade| looks over and prioritizes new contribution requests weekly.
    34→
    35→Expectations
    36→============
    37→
    38→Contribution tracking tickets are initially treated as on-call tickets and will be monitored by
    39→the primary on-call. The Golden Path Engineering team triages and distributes contributions
    40→once per week, then the follow-up will be prioritized alongside other project work. If your
    41→request is of high urgency but does not yet warrant :ref:`a Sev-2 <nade-severity-definition>`,
    42→please escalate to :phonetool-user:`snimakom`.
    43→
    44→If a tracking ticket is idle for more than 60 days and the next action item's owner is the contributor,
    45→the contribution tracking ticket will be closed and replaced by a feature request which will be noted in
    46→the original ticket. If the contributor has capacity to resume the contribution in the future, they
    47→need to open a new contribution request.
    48→
    49→
    50→What contributions we consider
    51→==============================
    52→
    53→In many cases, we're happy to take code contributions and improvements! Just provide a CR, and it
    54→will be reviewed by the relevant team(s).
    55→
    56→New templates
    57→-------------
    58→
    59→As we shift our products to depend more heavily on the Cloud Development Kit (CDK), our aim is to make
    60→templates smaller and more composable. Rather than authoring a template, you may be better served by
    61→:doc:`implementing a CDK construct <cdk-create-constructs-library>` that you can vend alongside documentation
    62→describing how your customers can adopt your construct as part of an existing :doc:`CDK Pipeline <create-cdk-pipeline>`.
    63→
    64→If you still think a new template is the right approach, then open a
    65→:sim:`BuilderHub Create vendor interest SIM <create?template=7610af6c-475b-4c0a-a14e-f845bbb5cfd9>`
    66→with the Hub team.
    67→
    68→New CloudFormation conditions and mappings
    69→------------------------------------------
    70→
    71→Adding new ``Conditions`` or ``Mappings`` to all consuming customer templates may result in
    72→`CloudFormation limits
    73→<https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/cloudformation-limits.html>`__
    74→being breached for individual customer teams. Instead, we would recommend generating your own Brazil
    75→package using our :codepkg:`BONESMappingTemplateGenerator`.
    76→
    77→Modifications to BONES Change Set Approver (CSA)
    78→------------------------------------------------
    79→
    80→We generally no longer accept new contributions for approval methods to CSA. CSA
    81→currently operates in :wiki:`KTLO` and we are not funded to support major
    82→changes. The :wiki:`Nucleotides team <Nucleotides>` is working to deliver a
    83→replacement to CSA in 2022, see SIM issue :sim:`NT-CG-2<NT-CG-2>` for more
    84→information. Crucially, as we've learned more about CSA we have come to discover
    85→that ChangeSets are generally the wrong approach: the diffs are not performed on
    86→fully resolved CloudFormation templates and do not take stack drift into
    87→account. As a result, approvers tend to have unexpected corner cases and failure
    88→modes that require the tool to be more conservative than is useful.
    89→
    90→.. _contributing-experts:
    91→
    92→Subject matter experts
    93→======================
    94→
    95→Given the broad adoption of |team-nade|-authored libraries, coupled with the complexity of some
    96→underlying technologies, behavioral changes to packages we own pose a risk of having unintended
    97→consequences companywide. To minimize this risk, the |team-nade| relies on subject matter experts
    98→for reviews and guidance when appropriate, including:
    99→
   100→* **AmazonLinux:** :wiki:`AmazonLinux team <AmazonLinux>`
   101→* **BATS/BARS:** :wiki:`Packaging team <BuilderTools/PackagingTeam>`
   102→* **CDK:** :wiki:`CDK team  <AWS/DeveloperResources/AWSSDKsAndTools/CDK>`
   103→* **Hydra:** :wiki:`TAP team <TestAutomationPlatform>`
   104→* **EC2 Launch Configuration:** :wiki:`SSM team <SystemsManager>`
   105→* **OS Patching:** :wiki:`Quilt team  <Quilt>`
   106→* **Pipeline Behavior:** :wiki:`CD team  <ContinuousDeploymentTeam>`
   107→* **Pipeline Synthesis:** :wiki:`LPT team  <Lpt>`
   108→* **Time Synchronization & Accuracy:** :wiki:`EC2 Chronos team <EC2/Chronos>`
   109→
   110→.. _contributing-products:
   111→
   112→Products
   113→========
   114→
   115→BONES Change Set Approver (CSA)
   116→-------------------------------
   117→
   118→CSA workflow approval step
   119→^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   120→
   121→The CSA approval step is run within customer pipelines to gain insight into new CloudFormation
   122→change sets before they are promoted and deployed. The logic for this approval step is defined
   123→within the :codepkg:`BONESChangeSetApproval` Brazil package.
   124→
   125→CSA website
   126→^^^^^^^^^^^
   127→
   128→The `CSA website <https://csa.bones.a2z.com/>`__ allows customers to approve change sets produced by
   129→the CSA approval step. Its logic is defined within the :codepkg:`BONESCSAWebsiteLambda` Brazil
   130→package and its dependent packages.
   131→
   132→
   133→BuilderHub/Create source applications
   134→-------------------------------------
   135→
   136→The Golden Path team owns several source applications in :bhcreate:`BuilderHub/Create <faq>`, including:
   137→
   138→* **BT101** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil <bt101>`)
   139→* **Coral Service on Fargate** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (AWS) <coral-fargate>`,
   140→  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (SDO) <coral-fargate>`)
   141→* **Coral Service on Lambda** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (AWS) <cle-java-lambda>`,
   142→  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (SDO) <cle-java-lambda>`)
   143→* **Basic GenAI Service** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Peru <genai-python-lambda>`)
   144→
   145→Contributions to these source applications must preserve parity.
   146→
   147→* There must be parity between packages belonging to a given source-application.
   148→  For example, if a source-application contains multiple packages in Java, then those packages ought to agree with one another in terms of formatting, JVM version, and build system.
   149→* There must be parity between flavors of an application. For example, the :guilabel:`Basic Java Lambda` applications is available for Brazil and for Peru.
   150→  It would not be desirable to migrate only one of them, say, onto a newer version of the JVM; they should differ only in terms of a single vertical.
   151→* There must be parity between source applications in terms of tooling support and integration.
   152→  For example, when we adopted Rosetta and Updatabot, those changes were made in tandem to all of our Peru-based source applications.
   153→
   154→When submitting a contribution that involves changes to multiple packages belonging to the same source application, it is desirable that the changes be released simultaneously
   155→to BuilderHub Create; thus, we prefer to receive the changes bundled into a single code review that we can merge. When submitting a contribution that involves changes to multiple source applications,
   156→there should be one such review per source application.
   157→
   158→CDK tooling and constructs
   159→--------------------------
   160→
   161→For customers wishing to use the CDK, we offer the ``cdk-build`` build system and a set of CDK
   162→constructs:
   163→
   164→.. list-table::
   165→   :header-rows: 1
   166→
   167→   * - NPM package
   168→     - Source package
   169→   * - :npmpkg:`@amzn/cdk-cli`
   170→     - :codepkg:`AmznCdkCli`, :codepkg:`CDKBuild`
   171→   * - :npmpkg:`@amzn/cdk-bones`
   172→     - :codepkg:`BONESConstructs`
   173→
   174→For vendors of CDK libraries, we provide the :codepkg:`JsiiBrazilmakCore` and :codepkg:`PeruJSII` build tools to support publishing
   175→CDK construct libraries in multiple languages.
   176→
   177→CfnBuild tooling and libraries
   178→------------------------------
   179→
   180→:codepkg:`CfnBuild` is an internal build system capable of combining partial CloudFormation
   181→templates to create a single, deployable template. In addition to the build system itself, the
   182→|team-nade| also vends Brazil package libraries containing partial CloudFormation templates that can
   183→be merged alongside resources you define yourself.
   184→
   185→Since customers are free to override portions of the templates vended within the below libraries,
   186→even small changes to existing resources may prove to be backwards-incompatible.
   187→
   188→EC2 libraries
   189→^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   190→
   191→.. hlist::
   192→   :columns: 2
   193→
   194→   * :codepkg:`BONESBastionTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   195→   * :codepkg:`BONESClassLB`
   196→   * :codepkg:`BONESConduitLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2`
   197→   * :codepkg:`BONESEc2KeyPairCustomLaunchConfig`
   198→   * :codepkg:`BONESEc2KeyPairCustomResource`
   199→   * :codepkg:`BONESIsengardLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2`
   200→   * :codepkg:`BONESIsengardLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   201→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplate`
   202→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   203→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   204→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceLaunchTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   205→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceLaunchTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   206→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   207→   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   208→   * :codepkg:`BONESSinglePassTemplate`
   209→   * :codepkg:`BONESWinterMigrationCodeDeployPatch`
   210→
   211→Networking libraries
   212→^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   213→
   214→.. hlist::
   215→   :columns: 2
   216→
   217→   * :codepkg:`BONESAutoDogfish`
   218→   * :codepkg:`BONESVpcTemplate`
   219→
   220→OS patching libraries
   221→^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   222→
   223→.. note:: The :wiki:`Quilt team  <Quilt>` has taken ownership of these OS patching libraries. Please
   224→   reach out to them for guidance on contributions.
   225→
   226→.. hlist::
   227→   :columns: 2

.. Copyright © 2023, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/


##################
Contribution guide
##################

.. meta::
   :description: Contribution guide for the Golden Path family of tooling
   :keywords: bones, native aws, naws, contribution, contributing

.. contents::
   :local:

Thanks for your interest in contributing to the |team-nade|’s services, tooling, libraries, and
templates!

.. _contributing-start:

Getting started
===============

For tracking purposes, :simt:`open an issue for our team <create/templates/aff28c08-a586-4456-b301-6c3d4e05230d>`.

The |team-nade| looks over and prioritizes new contribution requests weekly.

Expectations
============

Contribution tracking tickets are initially treated as on-call tickets and will be monitored by
the primary on-call. The Golden Path Engineering team triages and distributes contributions
once per week, then the follow-up will be prioritized alongside other project work. If your
request is of high urgency but does not yet warrant :ref:`a Sev-2 <nade-severity-definition>`,
please escalate to :phonetool-user:`snimakom`.

If a tracking ticket is idle for more than 60 days and the next action item's owner is the contributor,
the contribution tracking ticket will be closed and replaced by a feature request which will be noted in
the original ticket. If the contributor has capacity to resume the contribution in the future, they
need to open a new contribution request.


What contributions we consider
==============================

In many cases, we're happy to take code contributions and improvements! Just provide a CR, and it
will be reviewed by the relevant team(s).

New templates
-------------

As we shift our products to depend more heavily on the Cloud Development Kit (CDK), our aim is to make
templates smaller and more composable. Rather than authoring a template, you may be better served by
:doc:`implementing a CDK construct <cdk-create-constructs-library>` that you can vend alongside documentation
describing how your customers can adopt your construct as part of an existing :doc:`CDK Pipeline <create-cdk-pipeline>`.

If you still think a new template is the right approach, then open a
:sim:`BuilderHub Create vendor interest SIM <create?template=7610af6c-475b-4c0a-a14e-f845bbb5cfd9>`
with the Hub team.

New CloudFormation conditions and mappings
------------------------------------------

Adding new ``Conditions`` or ``Mappings`` to all consuming customer templates may result in
`CloudFormation limits
<https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/cloudformation-limits.html>`__
being breached for individual customer teams. Instead, we would recommend generating your own Brazil
package using our :codepkg:`BONESMappingTemplateGenerator`.

Modifications to BONES Change Set Approver (CSA)
------------------------------------------------

We generally no longer accept new contributions for approval methods to CSA. CSA
currently operates in :wiki:`KTLO` and we are not funded to support major
changes. The :wiki:`Nucleotides team <Nucleotides>` is working to deliver a
replacement to CSA in 2022, see SIM issue :sim:`NT-CG-2<NT-CG-2>` for more
information. Crucially, as we've learned more about CSA we have come to discover
that ChangeSets are generally the wrong approach: the diffs are not performed on
fully resolved CloudFormation templates and do not take stack drift into
account. As a result, approvers tend to have unexpected corner cases and failure
modes that require the tool to be more conservative than is useful.

.. _contributing-experts:

Subject matter experts
======================

Given the broad adoption of |team-nade|-authored libraries, coupled with the complexity of some
underlying technologies, behavioral changes to packages we own pose a risk of having unintended
consequences companywide. To minimize this risk, the |team-nade| relies on subject matter experts
for reviews and guidance when appropriate, including:

* **AmazonLinux:** :wiki:`AmazonLinux team <AmazonLinux>`
* **BATS/BARS:** :wiki:`Packaging team <BuilderTools/PackagingTeam>`
* **CDK:** :wiki:`CDK team  <AWS/DeveloperResources/AWSSDKsAndTools/CDK>`
* **Hydra:** :wiki:`TAP team <TestAutomationPlatform>`
* **EC2 Launch Configuration:** :wiki:`SSM team <SystemsManager>`
* **OS Patching:** :wiki:`Quilt team  <Quilt>`
* **Pipeline Behavior:** :wiki:`CD team  <ContinuousDeploymentTeam>`
* **Pipeline Synthesis:** :wiki:`LPT team  <Lpt>`
* **Time Synchronization & Accuracy:** :wiki:`EC2 Chronos team <EC2/Chronos>`

.. _contributing-products:

Products
========

BONES Change Set Approver (CSA)
-------------------------------

CSA workflow approval step
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

The CSA approval step is run within customer pipelines to gain insight into new CloudFormation
change sets before they are promoted and deployed. The logic for this approval step is defined
within the :codepkg:`BONESChangeSetApproval` Brazil package.

CSA website
^^^^^^^^^^^

The `CSA website <https://csa.bones.a2z.com/>`__ allows customers to approve change sets produced by
the CSA approval step. Its logic is defined within the :codepkg:`BONESCSAWebsiteLambda` Brazil
package and its dependent packages.


BuilderHub/Create source applications
-------------------------------------

The Golden Path team owns several source applications in :bhcreate:`BuilderHub/Create <faq>`, including:

* **BT101** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil <bt101>`)
* **Coral Service on Fargate** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (AWS) <coral-fargate>`,
  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (SDO) <coral-fargate>`)
* **Coral Service on Lambda** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (AWS) <cle-java-lambda>`,
  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Brazil (SDO) <cle-java-lambda>`)
* **Basic GenAI Service** (:bhcreate-srcapp:`Peru <genai-python-lambda>`)

Contributions to these source applications must preserve parity.

* There must be parity between packages belonging to a given source-application.
  For example, if a source-application contains multiple packages in Java, then those packages ought to agree with one another in terms of formatting, JVM version, and build system.
* There must be parity between flavors of an application. For example, the :guilabel:`Basic Java Lambda` applications is available for Brazil and for Peru.
  It would not be desirable to migrate only one of them, say, onto a newer version of the JVM; they should differ only in terms of a single vertical.
* There must be parity between source applications in terms of tooling support and integration.
  For example, when we adopted Rosetta and Updatabot, those changes were made in tandem to all of our Peru-based source applications.

When submitting a contribution that involves changes to multiple packages belonging to the same source application, it is desirable that the changes be released simultaneously
to BuilderHub Create; thus, we prefer to receive the changes bundled into a single code review that we can merge. When submitting a contribution that involves changes to multiple source applications,
there should be one such review per source application.

CDK tooling and constructs
--------------------------

For customers wishing to use the CDK, we offer the ``cdk-build`` build system and a set of CDK
constructs:

.. list-table::
   :header-rows: 1

   * - NPM package
     - Source package
   * - :npmpkg:`@amzn/cdk-cli`
     - :codepkg:`AmznCdkCli`, :codepkg:`CDKBuild`
   * - :npmpkg:`@amzn/cdk-bones`
     - :codepkg:`BONESConstructs`

For vendors of CDK libraries, we provide the :codepkg:`JsiiBrazilmakCore` and :codepkg:`PeruJSII` build tools to support publishing
CDK construct libraries in multiple languages.

CfnBuild tooling and libraries
------------------------------

:codepkg:`CfnBuild` is an internal build system capable of combining partial CloudFormation
templates to create a single, deployable template. In addition to the build system itself, the
|team-nade| also vends Brazil package libraries containing partial CloudFormation templates that can
be merged alongside resources you define yourself.

Since customers are free to override portions of the templates vended within the below libraries,
even small changes to existing resources may prove to be backwards-incompatible.

EC2 libraries
^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.. hlist::
   :columns: 2

   * :codepkg:`BONESBastionTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESClassLB`
   * :codepkg:`BONESConduitLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESEc2KeyPairCustomLaunchConfig`
   * :codepkg:`BONESEc2KeyPairCustomResource`
   * :codepkg:`BONESIsengardLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESIsengardLaunchConfigAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceASGsTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceLaunchTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceLaunchTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceTemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceTemplateAmazonLinux2AArch64`
   * :codepkg:`BONESSinglePassTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESWinterMigrationCodeDeployPatch`

Networking libraries
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.. hlist::
   :columns: 2

   * :codepkg:`BONESAutoDogfish`
   * :codepkg:`BONESVpcTemplate`

OS patching libraries
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.. note:: The :wiki:`Quilt team  <Quilt>` has taken ownership of these OS patching libraries. Please
   reach out to them for guidance on contributions.

.. hlist::
   :columns: 2

   * :codepkg:`BONESAMIUpdateCommonLib`
   * :codepkg:`BONESConduitAMITemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESConduitBastionAMITemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESIsengardAMITemplateAmazonLinux2`
   * :codepkg:`BONESRollingTerminate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESSSMPatchManagerTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESSSMPatchManagerTemplateAmazonLinux2`

Other supporting libraries
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.. hlist::
   :columns: 2

   * :codepkg:`BONESACMValidator`
   * :codepkg:`BONESArnMapping`
   * :codepkg:`BONESCertUploadCustomResource`
   * :codepkg:`BONESChangeSetRoleTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESCrossAccountDNSDelegator`
   * :codepkg:`BONESLptCommons`
   * :codepkg:`BONESMappingTemplateGenerator`
   * :codepkg:`BONESOdinEverywherePolicyTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESS3CustomCopy`
   * :codepkg:`BONESServiceMappingTemplate`
   * :codepkg:`BONESStaticWebsite`
   * :codepkg:`BONESStaticWebsitePython`
   * :codepkg:`DockerFileBuild`


Other types of contribution
===========================

.. toctree::
   :titlesonly:
   :maxdepth: 1

   cdk-contribute
   cdk-create-constructs-library

# BTDocs-BONES – BONES CLI Documentation Source

This is the source package for the BONES documentation on
[BuilderHub](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/).

The document sources themselves can be found in these directories:

* `tools_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/tools/bones/
* `docs_info` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/
* `cli_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/cli-guide/
* `user_guide` - contains the source for https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/bones/user-guide/


For important information about contributing to the docs, visit the [Contributing guide](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html) if you haven't already done so.


## Building the documentation

You can build the documentation on any development system (Cloud Desktop, Ubuntu or macOS system) using **`brazil-build`**. Run the following commands to set up your build environment:

    brazil ws create --root ~/workplace/btdocs --versionset BuilderHubDocs/BuilderHubDocs-peru

    cd ~/workplace/btdocs

    brazil ws use --package BTDocs-BONES

Once you have the package in your workspace, build it!

    cd ~/workplace/btdocs/src/BTDocs-BONES

    brazil-build

**Note** if **`brazil-build`** fails for some reason, make sure that you've set up your system according to the instructions [here](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/getting-started-dev-system.html).


## Viewing the documentation

Once the build completes, you'll find the built documentation in the `build/btdocs/` directory. You can view it by opening any of the built HTML files in your web browser, or by running:

    brazil-build server

Press **Ctrl+C** to stop the server.


## Additional resources

* [BuilderHub](https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com)
* [Writing Guide](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/index.html)
* [Builder Tools Documentation wiki](https://w.amazon.com/index.php/BuilderTools/Documentation)

*Share and enjoy!*

#
# BTDocs config -- For more information about the settings in this file, see:
#
# * https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/builder/btdocs-config.html
#

# The options in general_settings apply to all doc sets in this package.
general_settings:
  feedback_url: "https://t.corp.amazon.com/create/templates/2b08ebe1-f8e2-4b88-ad28-c6723fd16d07"
  local_include: "../shared/includes.txt"
  # The path (relative from within a doc set) to your product's logo. Comment
  # this out if you don't want a logo.
  # logo: "../shared/my-logo.png"
  local_extlinks: '../shared/extlinks.json'
  extra_source_files:
    - package: "BTDocsSharedContent"
      paths: ["shared/snippets=../shared_snippets"]
  default_author: "Golden Path Team <golden-path@amazon.com>"

# Settings per doc set. Each section within doc_sets is the name of the
# directory in which the source (.rst/.md files) for that set exists.
doc_sets:
  docs_info:
    title: "Native AWS Documentation"
    relative_url: "docs/native-aws/"
  event_consumers:
    title: "Building event consumers"
    relative_url: "docs/event-consumers/"
  developer_guide:
    title: "Native AWS Developer Guide"
    relative_url: "docs/native-aws/developer-guide/"
  golden_path:
    relative_url: "docs/golden-path/"
    title: "Golden Path recommendations"
  web_services:
    relative_url: "docs/web-services/"
    title: "Building web services"

Amazon's engineering best practices. +Paradigm +======== + +The tools that you use will depend largely on whether or not events may be processed discretely. +When your system receives an event *E*, should it be able to process that event without knowledge +(or :wikipedia:`state `) concerning prior events *E - 1*, *E - 2*, and so on? + +While a stateless system might simply validate, transform, or route individual messages one at a time, a +stateful system would be needed for operations like calculating running averages, detecting +patterns across multiple events, or maintaining aggregates over time windows, as these all require +persistent context about previous events. + +You should usually prefer **streaming** as a paradigm for systems that require stateful processing +and **messaging** otherwise. + Fair queuing ============ "},{"filePath":"event_consumers/messaging.rst","diff":"--- event_consumers/messaging.rst +++ event_consumers/messaging.rst @@ -23,17 +23,6 @@ Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -In *stateless* processing, each event or message is handled independently, without any need to know -about previous or future events; every piece of data can be processed in complete isolation. This -is in contrast to *stateful* processing, where the system maintains and remembers information across -multiple events to influence how current and future events are processed. For example, while a -stateless system might simply validate, transform, or route individual messages one at a time, a -stateful system would be needed for operations like calculating running averages, detecting -patterns across multiple events, or maintaining aggregates over time windows, as these all require -maintaining information about previous events. - -.. note:: When *stateful* processing is required, use :doc:`streaming` instead of messaging. - :aws:`Amazon SQS ` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via :wikipedia:`message passing `. It is a fully managed offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment "},{"filePath":"event_consumers/streaming.rst","diff":"--- event_consumers/streaming.rst +++ event_consumers/streaming.rst @@ -24,11 +24,6 @@ Prefer Amazon Kinesis Data Streams (KDS) for streaming with stateful processing ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -A system that performs *stateful* processing must maintain and recall information about prior -events to direct how current and future events are processed. In so doing, they can compute running -sums, detect patterns, and aggregate over periods. If an application does not require stateful -processing, then it should consider using :doc:`messaging` instead of streaming. - KDS is a :awsdocs:`scalable ` service for real-time data ingestion and processing. event_consumers/challenges.rst +++ event_consumers/challenges.rst @@ -28,6 +28,21 @@ you'll be better equipped to make informed design choices and implement effective solutions that align with Amazon's engineering best practices. +Paradigm +======== + +The tools that you use will depend largely on whether or not events may be processed discretely. +When your system receives an event *E*, should it be able to process that event without knowledge +(or :wikipedia:`state `) concerning prior events *E - 1*, *E - 2*, and so on? + +While a stateless system might simply validate, transform, or route individual messages one at a time, a +stateful system would be needed for operations like calculating running averages, detecting +patterns across multiple events, or maintaining aggregates over time windows, as these all require +persistent context about previous events. + +You should usually prefer **streaming** as a paradigm for systems that require stateful processing +and **messaging** otherwise. + Fair queuing ============ "},{"filePath":"event_consumers/messaging.rst","diff":"--- event_consumers/messaging.rst +++ event_consumers/messaging.rst @@ -23,17 +23,6 @@ Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -In *stateless* processing, each event or message is handled independently, without any need to know -about previous or future events; every piece of data can be processed in complete isolation. This -is in contrast to *stateful* processing, where the system maintains and remembers information across -multiple events to influence how current and future events are processed. For example, while a -stateless system might simply validate, transform, or route individual messages one at a time, a -stateful system would be needed for operations like calculating running averages, detecting -patterns across multiple events, or maintaining aggregates over time windows, as these all require -maintaining information about previous events. - -.. note:: When *stateful* processing is required, use :doc:`streaming` instead of messaging. - :aws:`Amazon SQS ` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via :wikipedia:`message passing `. It is a fully managed offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment "},{"filePath":"event_consumers/streaming.rst","diff":"--- event_consumers/streaming.rst +++ event_consumers/streaming.rst @@ -24,11 +24,6 @@ Prefer Amazon Kinesis Data Streams (KDS) for streaming with stateful processing ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -A system that performs *stateful* processing must maintain and recall information about prior -events to direct how current and future events are processed. In so doing, they can compute running -sums, detect patterns, and aggregate over periods. If an application does not require stateful -processing, then it should consider using :doc:`messaging` instead of streaming. - KDS is a :awsdocs:`scalable ` service for real-time data ingestion and processing. Its foremost primitive is the :awsdocs:`stream `. Streams are composed of *shards*, which "}]}}]}

+.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.
+
+   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
+
+   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
+   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/
+
+   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
+   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
+
+#################
+Stream processing
+#################
+
+.. contents::
+   :local:
+
+
+Recommendation
+==============
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda:
+
+Prefer AWS Lambda for processing streaming data in real time
+------------------------------------------------------------
+
+Among viable compute platforms, :aws:`AWS Lambda <lambda>` may not always be
+the most affordable, flexible, or powerful option; however, it **is** more abstract, accessible, and
+available than the alternatives. Lambda can consume streaming data from
+:awsdocs:`Kinesis Data Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html>` (KDS),
+:awsdocs:`DynamoDB Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>`, or
+:awsdocs:`Amazon Managed Streaming for Kafka <lambda/latest/dg/with-msk.html>` (MSK).
+
+Via an :awsdocs:`Event Source Mapping
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html>` (ESM),
+Lambda will deliver records from a stream to a :awsdocs:`function
+<lambda/latest/dg/concepts-basics.html#gettingstarted-concepts-function>` in **batches**. The
+function is required to be in the same `AWS region
+<https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region%28AWS%29/>`__ as the stream; however, it is permissible for
+them to be in different accounts. The maximum allowable number of messages per batch is specified
+via :awsdocs:`BatchSize
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-batchsize>`;
+any integer value from 1 to 10,000 is allowed, but Lambda will not deliver more than 6 MB of input
+per function invocation. You also may adjust the promptness with which Lambda will deliver new
+records via :awsdocs:`MaximumBatchingWindowInSeconds
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumbatchingwindowinseconds>`.
+If delay is tolerable, then you may choose to optimize for cost over latency by allowing time for
+records to accrue into fuller batches. Since Lambda bills per invocation, it will be cheaper to
+process (say) 100 records in 1 batch than in 10.
+
+If processing requires extended context about the stream (e.g., concerning prior batches), then may
+enable :awsdocs:`tumbling windows <lambda/latest/dg/services-kinesis-windows.html>` (albeit only for
+KDS and DynamoDB sources). In :aws:`this arrangement
+<blogs/compute/using-aws-lambda-for-streaming-analytics/>`, time is divided into a series of
+non-overlapping windows (up to 900 seconds apiece) and each stream record belongs to exactly one
+such window. With respect to each window, Lambda maintains persistent key-value context and
+repetitively invokes a function with the context as part of the input. Invocation N receives input
+and returns output, which propagates as context to invocation N + 1. You may configure a maximum
+size beyond which no window may grow; however, a given window will close prematurely if its state
+exceeds 1 MB.
+
+.. note::
+
+   It is not allowed to set :awsdocs:`ParallelizationFactor
+   <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-parallelizationfactor>`
+   to any value other than 1 when tumbling windows are enabled; this preempts any need for Lambda to
+   :wikipedia:`synchronize <Synchronization_(computer_science)>` access to the external context that
+   it provides.
+
+
+In :aws:`AWS CDK <cdk>`, you should generally use the :awsdocs:`aws_lambda_event_sources module
+<cdk/api/v2/docs/aws-cdk-lib.aws_lambda_event_sources-readme.html>` over working directly with an
+ESM.
+
+
+
+Best practices
+==============
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-enable-batch-errors-tandem:
+
+Enable ``BisectBatchOnFunctionError`` and ``ReportBatchItemFailures`` in tandem
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+When :awsdocs:`BatchSize
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-batchsiz>`
+is greater than 1, then you must account for scenarios in which processing makes **partial
+progress**. If the function returns an error in response to some input (and if permitted by the
+value of :awsdocs:`MaximumRetryAttempts
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumretryattempts>`),
+then Lambda will continue to attempt to deliver that input to the function. Consequently, it is
+possible that the function will reprocess records that successfully were processed by the prior
+invocation, which in turn may lead to problems such as double counting. In this respect, there is no
+substitute for :wikipedia:`idempotent <Idempotence>` business logic; however, there *are* steps that
+you may take in order to reduce the frequency with which records are processed redundantly.
+
+When the :awsdocs:`BisectBatchOnFunctionError
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-bisectbatchonfunctionerror>`
+flag is enabled, then Lambda will divide the initial batch of records into halves and deliver them
+one at a time; if the function returns *another* error while processing the first half, then it will
+be halved again and so on while retries remain. If you enable :awsdocs:`ReportBatchItemFailures
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-functionresponsetypes>`
+in tandem and :awsdocs:`craft your business logic accordingly
+<lambda/latest/dg/services-kinesis-batchfailurereporting.html>`, then Lambda instead will divide the
+batch such that only the first record that failed to be processed (and all subsequent records from
+the batch) are delivered on retry. You should enable both of these flags and abort your processing
+with an error immediately after any record fails to be processed.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-send-events-S3:
+
+Prefer to send events to Amazon S3 over other on-failure destinations
+---------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are applications in which ordered processing is such an inviolable
+requirement that you would rather suffer an outage than accept
+mitigations that do not honor that constraint. However, when an
+application *can* afford to compromise fidelity occasionally, then it is
+reasonable to **shed** work that cannot be processed so that other work
+may advance. In such cases, it is desirable to route these “dead
+letters” to another destination, which can preserve them for postmortem
+analysis.
+
+Lambda can shed batches from a stream to :awsdocs:`several potential destinations
+<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async-retain-records.html#invocation-async-destinations>`. However, it
+will propagate the payload **only** when :aws:`shedding to an S3 bucket
+<about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-lambda-s3-failed-event-destination-stream-event-sources/>`; no
+other destination can accommodate such (potentially) large content.
+
+.. note::
+
+   You **must** apply the same standard for security to content in the bucket, as to content in the
+   stream. We recommend alarming on any positive value of the ``DestinationDeliveryFailures`` metric
+   :awsdocs:`that Lambda will emit
+   <lambda/latest/dg/monitoring-metrics-types.html#invocation-metrics>` in case of misconfiguration.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-encrypt-filter-criteria-KMS:
+
+Encrypt filter criteria with a Key Management Service (KMS) customer-managed key (CMK)
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+It is possible that some consumer of a stream may be interested only in a subset of its records.
+Lambda can :awsdocs:`filter <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventfiltering.html#filtering-by-service>`
+all other records preemptively from the batches that it delivers to that function. However, the
+definitions of these filters necessarily will expose facts about the shapes of the records in the
+stream (e.g., the names of their properties). Consequently, you should apply the same standard for
+security to the body of a filter as to the content of the stream.
+
+:awsdocs:`KmsKeyArn
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-kmskeyarn>`
+may reference an AWS-owned key or a CMK. `It is preferred
+<https://www.aristotle.a2z.com/recommendations/212>`__ to use a CMK, which provides
+:wikipedia:`defense in depth <Defense_in_depth_(computing)>` should permissions otherwise have been
+granted too broadly via role policies and/or resource policies. It also will cause CloudTrail to log
+an event whenever the encrypted data is accessed.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-enable-additional-metrics:
+
+Enable additional metrics that measure the flow of data from event sources
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+Lambda ESM can enable additional metrics concerning the flow of traffic from a stream to a function
+via :awsdocs:`MetricsConfig
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-metricsconfig>`.
+However, you must elect to receive them. They are either altogether enabled or altogether disabled;
+you cannot enable them selectively. Configure the :awsdocs:`recommended set of alarms
+<lambda/latest/dg/monitoring-metrics-types.html#event-source-mapping-metrics>` upon these metrics.
+
+
+Caveats
+=======
+
+
+Event source mappings do not fully support Apache Kafka
+-------------------------------------------------------
+
+Lambda is able to :awsdocs:`process streaming data from Kafka. <lambda/latest/dg/with-msk.html>`.
+However, this integration lacks support for some of the features that are available when processing
+streams from :awsdocs:`Amazon Kinesis Data Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html>` or from
+:awsdocs:`Amazon DynamoDB Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>`.
+
+The following relevant behaviors are unavailable
+when streaming to Lambda from Kafka:
+
+- :awsdocs:`BisectBatchOnFunctionError
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-bisectbatchonfunctionerror>`
+- :awsdocs:`MaximumRecordAgeInSeconds
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumrecordageinseconds>`
+- :awsdocs:`MaximumRetryAttempts
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumretryattempts>`
+- :awsdocs:`MetricsConfig
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-metricsconfig>`
+- :awsdocs:`ParallelizationFactor
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-parallelizationfactor>`
+- :awsdocs:`TumblingWindowInSeconds
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-tumblingwindowinseconds>`
+
+
+Schema registries are supported for Apache Kafka only
+-----------------------------------------------------
+
+AWS :awsdocs:`Glue Schema Registry <glue/latest/dg/schema-registry.html>` (GSR) is a centralized
+bank for data formats. It enables producers to form contracts with their consumers in terms of the
+shape(s) of the data that may pass between them. These contracts are a foundation upon which you may
+build runtime validations and (de)serialization routines. In brief, their role is analogous to that
+which `Smithy <https://smithy.io/>`__ models play in service contexts. GSR accepts formats defined
+in terms of `Avro <https://avro.apache.org/>`__, :wikipedia:`JSON <JSON>`, and
+:wikipedia:`Protobuf <Protocol_Buffers>`. It :awsdocs:`supports versioning
+<glue/latest/dg/schema-registry.html#schema-registry-compatibility>` and can validate proposed
+changes to a schema based upon selected rules (e.g., backwards compatibility).
+
+Lambda natively :aws:`integrates
+<about-aws/whats-new/2025/06/aws-lambda-native-support-avro-protobuf-kafka-events/>` with GSR (in
+regions where it is available), but only with respect to `Apache Kafka
+<https://kafka.apache.org/>`__ event sources.
+
+
+Driving records from an on-failure destination back to a Lambda function is not natively supported
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are many possible reasons for which a function may fail to process a given batch of records.
+When the fault is with the payload (e.g., invalid encoding), then it may be appropriate simply to
+discard the batch (e.g., in favor of repairing the upstream problem and then re-driving valid data
+from there). However, when the fault is with your own business logic or a downstream dependency,
+then it is reasonable to want to `reprocess the payload
+<https://repost.aws/questions/QUe9LjFwCJTCKVvMsreFQfVQ/best-practice-to-redrive-events-from-a-lambda-dlq>`__
+once the fault is resolved.
+
+Unfortunately, there presently is no native support for this pattern.
+Builders will need to evolve their own tooling for driving work back to
+a function from its on-failure destination(s).
+
+.. warning::
+
+   **Do not** automatically
+   loop messages from an on-failure destination back to the function by
+   adding the on-failure destination as another event source; traffic
+   should not be replayed until an operator can confirm that it is safe to
+   do so.
+
+
+Data can be lost when using Lambda with Kinesis aggregation and enhanced fan-out (EFO)
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+The :awsdocs:`Kinesis Producer Library <streams/latest/dev/developing-producers-with-kpl.html>`
+(KPL) can :awsdocs:`aggregate
+<streams/latest/dev/kinesis-kpl-concepts.html#kinesis-kpl-concepts-aggretation>` multiple raw data
+records into a combined Kinesis stream record, which increases the effective throughput of the
+stream. This behavior has been encapsulated `into a module
+<https://github.com/awslabs/kinesis-aggregation>`__ that is available independently of the rest of
+the KPL, but be aware of the `potential for data loss
+<https://github.com/awslabs/kinesis-aggregation/blob/master/potential_data_loss.md>`__.
+
+The KPL will aggregate only records that share a common shard (based on the shard's
+:awsdocs:`hash key range<kinesis/latest/APIReference/API_HashKeyRange.html>`),
+but the standalone module critically **does not enforce this**. The 1.x
+version of the :awsdocs:`Kinesis Client Library <streams/latest/dev/kcl.html>`
+(KCL) did not enforce it either, but subsequent versions **will drop**
+any raw data record whose partition key does not match that of the
+aggregate stream record.
+
+The support in Lambda ESM for EFO streams is implemented upon the 2.x version of the KCL.
+Consequently, it :awsdocs:`inherits the behavior of shedding records
+<lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html#kinesis-polling-and-batching>` with mismatched partition keys;
+they are not delivered to functions, nor even to configured on-failure destinations, and the
+behavior is not directly observable as a metric. Producers should use the KPL to avoid this.
+
+
+DynamoDB streams must be in the same account as consumer Lambda functions
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+A :awsdocs:`DynamoDB stream <amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Streams.html>` may be
+:awsdocs:`mapped as an event source <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>` for a Lambda function
+:awsdocs:`only if they are in the same AWS account
+<amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Streams.Lambda.html>`. This gap is being worked on and will be
+addressed in the coming months. You may circumvent this limitation in the meantime by
+:awsdocs:`streaming from DynamoDB with Kinesis Data Streams
+<amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/kds.html>` instead, but be aware of :awsdocs:`the differences
+in behavior <amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/streamsmain.html#streamsmain.choose>`.
+
+
+Lambda functions mapped onto Kafka sources may not execute for more than 840 seconds
+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+The maximum allowable timeout for a Lambda function :awsdocs:`is 900 seconds
+<lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-limits.html#function-configuration-deployment-and-execution>`.
+However, Lambda functions that consume from Kafka sources :awsdocs:`must timeout within 840 seconds
+<lambda/latest/dg/with-msk-configure.html>`. This constraint is due to the particular implementation
+in Lambda of support for these sources (which, itself, was built upon Lambda).
+
+
+Alternatives considered
+=======================
+
+
+.. _amazon-managed-service-for-msf:
+
+Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flink (MSF)
+---------------------------------------------
+
+`Apache Flink <https://flink.apache.org/>`__ is an industry-standard open-source framework
+(supporting Java, Scala, `and Python
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/python/overview/>`__) for
+building distributed stream analytics at scale. In this context, its capabilities dwarf those of
+Lambda in terms of sophistication and complexity.
+
+Flink supports `four distinct API layers
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/overview/>`__.
+These layers are listed here in a hierarchy from highest to lowest level of abstraction:
+
+.. list-table:: **Flink API Layers**
+   :widths: 20 80
+   :header-rows: 1
+
+   * - **API Layer**
+     - **Description**
+   * - **SQL**
+     - `Implementation
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/sql/overview/>`__
+       of the :aws:`SQL <what-is/sql/>` standard based on `Apache Calcite
+       <https://calcite.apache.org/>`__.
+   * - **Table API**
+     - The `Table API
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ is a
+       declarative `domain-specific language
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ (DSL)
+       based on the :wikipedia:`relational model <Relational_model>` (RM). Via this layer, you
+       define tables as schemas and then query them with APIs that implement typical relational
+       operators, for example, ``select()``. The SQL layer is interoperable with schemas defined by
+       the Table API.
+   * - **Core API**
+     - The **Core API** is chiefly based on the `DataStream object
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/datastream/DataStream.html>`__.
+       It's fundamental building blocks: `sources
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sources>`__,
+       `sinks
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sinks>`__,
+       and the `transforms
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/overview/>`__
+       between them.
+   * - **ProcessFunction**
+     - Lowest level of abstraction embedded in the Core API. Exposed via the abstract
+       `ProcessFunction
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/functions/ProcessFunction.html>`__
+       that can `access and work in terms
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/process_function/>`__
+       of the primitive elements of a ``DataStream``.
+
+In order to facilitate `stateful stream processing
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/stateful-stream-processing/>`__,
+a `Flink cluster
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/flink-architecture/>`__
+maintains context about the stream in a dedicated `state backend
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/ops/state/state_backends/>`__. Flink
+supports three different kinds of backend:
+
+- The ``HashMapStateBackend`` is the default option and is managed
+  in-memory via the Java
+  :wikipedia:`heap <Memory_management>`.
+- The ``EmbeddedRocksDBStateBackend`` option manages data on the disk of the `task manager
+  <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/flink-architecture/#taskmanagers>`__
+  (using `RocksDB <https://rocksdb.org/>`__).
+- The ``ForStStateBackend`` option (based on `the ForST project
+  <https://github.com/ververica/ForSt>`__) manages data in a key-value store, which is implemented
+  on top of RocksDB as a :wikipedia:`log-structured merge tree <Log-structured_merge-tree>` (LSMT).
+  The `Sorted String Table
+  <https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/wiki/A-Tutorial-of-RocksDB-SST-formats>`__ (SST) files that
+  comprise the database can be distributed onto remote storage, such as the :wikipedia:`Hadoop
+  Distributed File System <Apache_Hadoop#HDFS>` (HDFS) or Amazon S3. This enables the size of the
+  context to scale beyond the disk capacity of the task manager. **However**, it currently is in an
+  experimental stage and **must not** be enabled for any production use.
+
+Flink also supports `timely stream processing
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/time/>`__, which is an
+extension of stateful processing in which chronology is relevant.
+
+:aws:`Amazon MSF <managed-service-apache-flink/>` (:aws:`formerly known as Amazon Kinesis Data
+Analytics
+<blogs/aws/announcing-amazon-managed-service-for-apache-flink-renamed-from-amazon-kinesis-data-analytics/>`)
+is a managed platform for provisioning and operating Flink clusters. It enriches the functionality
+that Flink natively provides by enabling integrations with other AWS services (e.g., CloudWatch,
+Glue Schema Registry, Kinesis, S3, and EC2 VPC). You may deploy your Flink application code to MSF
+as a :wikipedia:`JAR <JAR_(file_format)>` from S3 (setting :awsdocs:`CodeContentType
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-properties-kinesisanalyticsv2-application-applicationcodeconfiguration.html#cfn-kinesisanalyticsv2-application-applicationcodeconfiguration-codecontenttype>`
+to ``ZIPFILE``), which is compatible with :doc:`the archetypal internal deployment tool-chain
+<nativedg:native-aws-mental-model>` at Amazon. For interactive development, MSF provides a
+serverless :awsdocs:`notebook experience <managed-flink/latest/java/how-notebook.html>` based on
+`Apache Zeppelin <https://zeppelin.apache.org/>`__.
+
+In terms of capability and pricing, MSF is considerably more apt than Lambda for stateful stream
+processing. However, in the context of internal development at Amazon, there are additional factors
+that must be considered. Unfortunately, MSF is `unavailable in certain regions
+<https://regions.aws.dev/services/statuses/kinesisanalytics>`__ and is not a launch-blocking service
+in new region builds. Furthermore, although there is :awsdocs:`CloudFormation support
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-kinesisanalyticsv2-application.html>` for
+MSF applications, you will be required to :awsdocs:`build your own support
+<managed-flink/latest/java/lambda-cfn-flink.html>` to (re)start an application after it has been
+created or updated. Additionally, applications must have :awsdocs:`maintenance windows
+<managed-flink/latest/java/maintenance.html>`, which is at odds with the goal of designing an
+application that can react to events on demand at all times. Finally, MSF does not support certain
+internal standards for security and operational excellence (e.g., incremental deployment, encryption
+with KMS customer-managed keys). For these reasons, it is difficult to recommend MSF for internal
+use despite its relevant strengths.
+
+
+Amazon EventBridge Pipes
+------------------------
+
+:awsdocs:`Amazon EventBridge Pipes <eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes.html>` is a service that
+enables point-to-point delivery between myriad pairs of :awsdocs:`sources
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-source.html>` and :awsdocs:`targets
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-target.html>`. It provides mechanisms for
+:awsdocs:`enrichment <eventbridge/latest/userguide/pipes-enrichment.html>`, :awsdocs:`filtering
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-filtering.html>`, and :awsdocs:`transformations
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-input-transformation.html>`. Builders commonly use Lambda
+functions to implement these behaviors today; in supported contexts, a pipe behaves as a zero-code
+replacement.
+
+It is feasible for a pipe to deliver records from a stream to a Lambda function (as an alternative
+to Lambda ESM). However, there are compelling reasons not to do this. Firstly, if an application is
+not otherwise using EventBridge Pipes, then it will introduce an additional service dependency, and
+EventBridge Pipes is `unavailable in some regions
+<https://regions.aws.dev/services/statuses/pipes>`__. Secondly, there are certain features available
+via ESM that are not supported via Pipes (e.g., tumbling windows, S3 as an on-failure destination).
+In absence of a strong incentive to the contrary, builders using Lambda should prefer ESM over
+Pipes.

find this section hard to grok visually, with the bullet list format. I suggest using a table. Here's a suggested approach:


```rst
Flink supports `four distinct API layers
<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/overview/>`__ arranged in a hierarchy from highest to lowest level of abstraction:

.. list-table:: **Flink API Layers**
   :widths: 20 80
   :header-rows: 1
   
   * - **API Layer**
     - **Description**
   * - **SQL**
     - `Implementation <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/sql/overview/>`__ 
       of the :aws:`SQL <what-is/sql/>` standard based on `Apache Calcite <https://calcite.apache.org/>`__. 
       Highest level of abstraction.
   * - **Table API**
     - `Declarative DSL <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ 
       based on the :wikipedia:`relational model <Relational_model>`. 
       Define tables as schemas and query with relational operators like ``select()``. 
       Interoperable with the SQL layer.
   * - **Core API**
     - Based on the `DataStream object <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/datastream/DataStream.html>`__
       with fundamental building blocks: `sources <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sources>`__, 
       `sinks <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sinks>`__, 
       and `transforms <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/overview/>`__.
   * - **ProcessFunction**
     - Lowest level of abstraction embedded in the Core API. Exposed via the abstract 
       `ProcessFunction <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/functions/ProcessFunction.html>`__
       that can `access and manipulate <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/process_function/>`__
       primitive elements of a ``DataStream``.
```

I'd also recommend using [anonymous](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/links-references/#anonymous-links) or [named](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/links-references/#named-links) links for all those long URLs to external Apache docs. Probably better to go with anonymous since they all seems to be unique?
