+.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.
+
+   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
+
+   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
+   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/
+
+   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
+   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
+
+#################
+Stream processing
+#################
+
+.. contents::
+   :local:
+
+
+Recommendation
+==============
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda:
+
+Prefer AWS Lambda for processing streaming data in real time
+------------------------------------------------------------
+
+Among viable compute platforms, :aws:`AWS Lambda <lambda>` may not always be
+the most affordable, flexible, or powerful option; however, it **is** more abstract, accessible, and
+available than the alternatives. Lambda can consume streaming data from
+:awsdocs:`Kinesis Data Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html>` (KDS),
+:awsdocs:`DynamoDB Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>`, or
+:awsdocs:`Amazon Managed Streaming for Kafka <lambda/latest/dg/with-msk.html>` (MSK).
+
+Via an :awsdocs:`Event Source Mapping
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html>` (ESM),
+Lambda will deliver records from a stream to a :awsdocs:`function
+<lambda/latest/dg/concepts-basics.html#gettingstarted-concepts-function>` in **batches**. The
+function is required to be in the same `AWS region
+<https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Region%28AWS%29/>`__ as the stream; however, it is permissible for
+them to be in different accounts. The maximum allowable number of messages per batch is specified
+via :awsdocs:`BatchSize
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-batchsize>`;
+any integer value from 1 to 10,000 is allowed, but Lambda will not deliver more than 6 MB of input
+per function invocation. You also may adjust the promptness with which Lambda will deliver new
+records via :awsdocs:`MaximumBatchingWindowInSeconds
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumbatchingwindowinseconds>`.
+If delay is tolerable, then you may choose to optimize for cost over latency by allowing time for
+records to accrue into fuller batches. Since Lambda bills per invocation, it will be cheaper to
+process (say) 100 records in 1 batch than in 10.
+
+If processing requires extended context about the stream (e.g., concerning prior batches), then may
+enable :awsdocs:`tumbling windows <lambda/latest/dg/services-kinesis-windows.html>` (albeit only for
+KDS and DynamoDB sources). In :aws:`this arrangement
+<blogs/compute/using-aws-lambda-for-streaming-analytics/>`, time is divided into a series of
+non-overlapping windows (up to 900 seconds apiece) and each stream record belongs to exactly one
+such window. With respect to each window, Lambda maintains persistent key-value context and
+repetitively invokes a function with the context as part of the input. Invocation N receives input
+and returns output, which propagates as context to invocation N + 1. You may configure a maximum
+size beyond which no window may grow; however, a given window will close prematurely if its state
+exceeds 1 MB.
+
+.. note::
+
+   It is not allowed to set :awsdocs:`ParallelizationFactor
+   <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-parallelizationfactor>`
+   to any value other than 1 when tumbling windows are enabled; this preempts any need for Lambda to
+   :wikipedia:`synchronize <Synchronization_(computer_science)>` access to the external context that
+   it provides.
+
+
+In :aws:`AWS CDK <cdk>`, you should generally use the :awsdocs:`aws_lambda_event_sources module
+<cdk/api/v2/docs/aws-cdk-lib.aws_lambda_event_sources-readme.html>` over working directly with an
+ESM.
+
+
+
+Best practices
+==============
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-enable-batch-errors-tandem:
+
+Enable ``BisectBatchOnFunctionError`` and ``ReportBatchItemFailures`` in tandem
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+When :awsdocs:`BatchSize
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-batchsiz>`
+is greater than 1, then you must account for scenarios in which processing makes **partial
+progress**. If the function returns an error in response to some input (and if permitted by the
+value of :awsdocs:`MaximumRetryAttempts
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumretryattempts>`),
+then Lambda will continue to attempt to deliver that input to the function. Consequently, it is
+possible that the function will reprocess records that successfully were processed by the prior
+invocation, which in turn may lead to problems such as double counting. In this respect, there is no
+substitute for :wikipedia:`idempotent <Idempotence>` business logic; however, there *are* steps that
+you may take in order to reduce the frequency with which records are processed redundantly.
+
+When the :awsdocs:`BisectBatchOnFunctionError
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-bisectbatchonfunctionerror>`
+flag is enabled, then Lambda will divide the initial batch of records into halves and deliver them
+one at a time; if the function returns *another* error while processing the first half, then it will
+be halved again and so on while retries remain. If you enable :awsdocs:`ReportBatchItemFailures
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-functionresponsetypes>`
+in tandem and :awsdocs:`craft your business logic accordingly
+<lambda/latest/dg/services-kinesis-batchfailurereporting.html>`, then Lambda instead will divide the
+batch such that only the first record that failed to be processed (and all subsequent records from
+the batch) are delivered on retry. You should enable both of these flags and abort your processing
+with an error immediately after any record fails to be processed.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-send-events-S3:
+
+Prefer to send events to Amazon S3 over other on-failure destinations
+---------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are applications in which ordered processing is such an inviolable
+requirement that you would rather suffer an outage than accept
+mitigations that do not honor that constraint. However, when an
+application *can* afford to compromise fidelity occasionally, then it is
+reasonable to **shed** work that cannot be processed so that other work
+may advance. In such cases, it is desirable to route these “dead
+letters” to another destination, which can preserve them for postmortem
+analysis.
+
+Lambda can shed batches from a stream to :awsdocs:`several potential destinations
+<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async-retain-records.html#invocation-async-destinations>`. However, it
+will propagate the payload **only** when :aws:`shedding to an S3 bucket
+<about-aws/whats-new/2024/11/aws-lambda-s3-failed-event-destination-stream-event-sources/>`; no
+other destination can accommodate such (potentially) large content.
+
+.. note::
+
+   You **must** apply the same standard for security to content in the bucket, as to content in the
+   stream. We recommend alarming on any positive value of the ``DestinationDeliveryFailures`` metric
+   :awsdocs:`that Lambda will emit
+   <lambda/latest/dg/monitoring-metrics-types.html#invocation-metrics>` in case of misconfiguration.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-encrypt-filter-criteria-KMS:
+
+Encrypt filter criteria with a Key Management Service (KMS) customer-managed key (CMK)
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+It is possible that some consumer of a stream may be interested only in a subset of its records.
+Lambda can :awsdocs:`filter <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventfiltering.html#filtering-by-service>`
+all other records preemptively from the batches that it delivers to that function. However, the
+definitions of these filters necessarily will expose facts about the shapes of the records in the
+stream (e.g., the names of their properties). Consequently, you should apply the same standard for
+security to the body of a filter as to the content of the stream.
+
+:awsdocs:`KmsKeyArn
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-kmskeyarn>`
+may reference an AWS-owned key or a CMK. `It is preferred
+<https://www.aristotle.a2z.com/recommendations/212>`__ to use a CMK, which provides
+:wikipedia:`defense in depth <Defense_in_depth_(computing)>` should permissions otherwise have been
+granted too broadly via role policies and/or resource policies. It also will cause CloudTrail to log
+an event whenever the encrypted data is accessed.
+
+
+.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-enable-additional-metrics:
+
+Enable additional metrics that measure the flow of data from event sources
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+Lambda ESM can enable additional metrics concerning the flow of traffic from a stream to a function
+via :awsdocs:`MetricsConfig
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-metricsconfig>`.
+However, you must elect to receive them. They are either altogether enabled or altogether disabled;
+you cannot enable them selectively. Configure the :awsdocs:`recommended set of alarms
+<lambda/latest/dg/monitoring-metrics-types.html#event-source-mapping-metrics>` upon these metrics.
+
+
+Caveats
+=======
+
+
+Event source mappings do not fully support Apache Kafka
+-------------------------------------------------------
+
+Lambda is able to :awsdocs:`process streaming data from Kafka. <lambda/latest/dg/with-msk.html>`.
+However, this integration lacks support for some of the features that are available when processing
+streams from :awsdocs:`Amazon Kinesis Data Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html>` or from
+:awsdocs:`Amazon DynamoDB Streams <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>`.
+
+The following relevant behaviors are unavailable
+when streaming to Lambda from Kafka:
+
+- :awsdocs:`BisectBatchOnFunctionError
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-bisectbatchonfunctionerror>`
+- :awsdocs:`MaximumRecordAgeInSeconds
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumrecordageinseconds>`
+- :awsdocs:`MaximumRetryAttempts
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-maximumretryattempts>`
+- :awsdocs:`MetricsConfig
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-metricsconfig>`
+- :awsdocs:`ParallelizationFactor
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-parallelizationfactor>`
+- :awsdocs:`TumblingWindowInSeconds
+  <AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-lambda-eventsourcemapping.html#cfn-lambda-eventsourcemapping-tumblingwindowinseconds>`
+
+
+Schema registries are supported for Apache Kafka only
+-----------------------------------------------------
+
+AWS :awsdocs:`Glue Schema Registry <glue/latest/dg/schema-registry.html>` (GSR) is a centralized
+bank for data formats. It enables producers to form contracts with their consumers in terms of the
+shape(s) of the data that may pass between them. These contracts are a foundation upon which you may
+build runtime validations and (de)serialization routines. In brief, their role is analogous to that
+which `Smithy <https://smithy.io/>`__ models play in service contexts. GSR accepts formats defined
+in terms of `Avro <https://avro.apache.org/>`__, :wikipedia:`JSON <JSON>`, and
+:wikipedia:`Protobuf <Protocol_Buffers>`. It :awsdocs:`supports versioning
+<glue/latest/dg/schema-registry.html#schema-registry-compatibility>` and can validate proposed
+changes to a schema based upon selected rules (e.g., backwards compatibility).
+
+Lambda natively :aws:`integrates
+<about-aws/whats-new/2025/06/aws-lambda-native-support-avro-protobuf-kafka-events/>` with GSR (in
+regions where it is available), but only with respect to `Apache Kafka
+<https://kafka.apache.org/>`__ event sources.
+
+
+Driving records from an on-failure destination back to a Lambda function is not natively supported
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+There are many possible reasons for which a function may fail to process a given batch of records.
+When the fault is with the payload (e.g., invalid encoding), then it may be appropriate simply to
+discard the batch (e.g., in favor of repairing the upstream problem and then re-driving valid data
+from there). However, when the fault is with your own business logic or a downstream dependency,
+then it is reasonable to want to `reprocess the payload
+<https://repost.aws/questions/QUe9LjFwCJTCKVvMsreFQfVQ/best-practice-to-redrive-events-from-a-lambda-dlq>`__
+once the fault is resolved.
+
+Unfortunately, there presently is no native support for this pattern.
+Builders will need to evolve their own tooling for driving work back to
+a function from its on-failure destination(s).
+
+.. warning::
+
+   **Do not** automatically
+   loop messages from an on-failure destination back to the function by
+   adding the on-failure destination as another event source; traffic
+   should not be replayed until an operator can confirm that it is safe to
+   do so.
+
+
+Data can be lost when using Lambda with Kinesis aggregation and enhanced fan-out (EFO)
+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+The :awsdocs:`Kinesis Producer Library <streams/latest/dev/developing-producers-with-kpl.html>`
+(KPL) can :awsdocs:`aggregate
+<streams/latest/dev/kinesis-kpl-concepts.html#kinesis-kpl-concepts-aggretation>` multiple raw data
+records into a combined Kinesis stream record, which increases the effective throughput of the
+stream. This behavior has been encapsulated `into a module
+<https://github.com/awslabs/kinesis-aggregation>`__ that is available independently of the rest of
+the KPL, but be aware of the `potential for data loss
+<https://github.com/awslabs/kinesis-aggregation/blob/master/potential_data_loss.md>`__.
+
+The KPL will aggregate only records that share a common shard (based on the shard's
+:awsdocs:`hash key range<kinesis/latest/APIReference/API_HashKeyRange.html>`),
+but the standalone module critically **does not enforce this**. The 1.x
+version of the :awsdocs:`Kinesis Client Library <streams/latest/dev/kcl.html>`
+(KCL) did not enforce it either, but subsequent versions **will drop**
+any raw data record whose partition key does not match that of the
+aggregate stream record.
+
+The support in Lambda ESM for EFO streams is implemented upon the 2.x version of the KCL.
+Consequently, it :awsdocs:`inherits the behavior of shedding records
+<lambda/latest/dg/with-kinesis.html#kinesis-polling-and-batching>` with mismatched partition keys;
+they are not delivered to functions, nor even to configured on-failure destinations, and the
+behavior is not directly observable as a metric. Producers should use the KPL to avoid this.
+
+
+DynamoDB streams must be in the same account as consumer Lambda functions
+-------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+A :awsdocs:`DynamoDB stream <amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Streams.html>` may be
+:awsdocs:`mapped as an event source <lambda/latest/dg/with-ddb.html>` for a Lambda function
+:awsdocs:`only if they are in the same AWS account
+<amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Streams.Lambda.html>`. This gap is being worked on and will be
+addressed in the coming months. You may circumvent this limitation in the meantime by
+:awsdocs:`streaming from DynamoDB with Kinesis Data Streams
+<amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/kds.html>` instead, but be aware of :awsdocs:`the differences
+in behavior <amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/streamsmain.html#streamsmain.choose>`.
+
+
+Lambda functions mapped onto Kafka sources may not execute for more than 840 seconds
+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
+
+The maximum allowable timeout for a Lambda function :awsdocs:`is 900 seconds
+<lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-limits.html#function-configuration-deployment-and-execution>`.
+However, Lambda functions that consume from Kafka sources :awsdocs:`must timeout within 840 seconds
+<lambda/latest/dg/with-msk-configure.html>`. This constraint is due to the particular implementation
+in Lambda of support for these sources (which, itself, was built upon Lambda).
+
+
+Alternatives considered
+=======================
+
+
+.. _amazon-managed-service-for-msf:
+
+Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flink (MSF)
+---------------------------------------------
+
+`Apache Flink <https://flink.apache.org/>`__ is an industry-standard open-source framework
+(supporting Java, Scala, `and Python
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/python/overview/>`__) for
+building distributed stream analytics at scale. In this context, its capabilities dwarf those of
+Lambda in terms of sophistication and complexity.
+
+Flink supports `four distinct API layers
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/overview/>`__.
+These layers are listed here in a hierarchy from highest to lowest level of abstraction:
+
+.. list-table:: **Flink API Layers**
+   :widths: 20 80
+   :header-rows: 1
+
+   * - **API Layer**
+     - **Description**
+   * - **SQL**
+     - `Implementation
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/sql/overview/>`__
+       of the :aws:`SQL <what-is/sql/>` standard based on `Apache Calcite
+       <https://calcite.apache.org/>`__.
+   * - **Table API**
+     - The `Table API
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ is a
+       declarative `domain-specific language
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ (DSL)
+       based on the :wikipedia:`relational model <Relational_model>` (RM). Via this layer, you
+       define tables as schemas and then query them with APIs that implement typical relational
+       operators, for example, ``select()``. The SQL layer is interoperable with schemas defined by
+       the Table API.
+   * - **Core API**
+     - The **Core API** is chiefly based on the `DataStream object
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/datastream/DataStream.html>`__.
+       It's fundamental building blocks: `sources
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sources>`__,
+       `sinks
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sinks>`__,
+       and the `transforms
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/overview/>`__
+       between them.
+   * - **ProcessFunction**
+     - Lowest level of abstraction embedded in the Core API. Exposed via the abstract
+       `ProcessFunction
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/functions/ProcessFunction.html>`__
+       that can `access and work in terms
+       <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/process_function/>`__
+       of the primitive elements of a ``DataStream``.
+
+In order to facilitate `stateful stream processing
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/stateful-stream-processing/>`__,
+a `Flink cluster
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/flink-architecture/>`__
+maintains context about the stream in a dedicated `state backend
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/ops/state/state_backends/>`__. Flink
+supports three different kinds of backend:
+
+- The ``HashMapStateBackend`` is the default option and is managed
+  in-memory via the Java
+  :wikipedia:`heap <Memory_management>`.
+- The ``EmbeddedRocksDBStateBackend`` option manages data on the disk of the `task manager
+  <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/flink-architecture/#taskmanagers>`__
+  (using `RocksDB <https://rocksdb.org/>`__).
+- The ``ForStStateBackend`` option (based on `the ForST project
+  <https://github.com/ververica/ForSt>`__) manages data in a key-value store, which is implemented
+  on top of RocksDB as a :wikipedia:`log-structured merge tree <Log-structured_merge-tree>` (LSMT).
+  The `Sorted String Table
+  <https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/wiki/A-Tutorial-of-RocksDB-SST-formats>`__ (SST) files that
+  comprise the database can be distributed onto remote storage, such as the :wikipedia:`Hadoop
+  Distributed File System <Apache_Hadoop#HDFS>` (HDFS) or Amazon S3. This enables the size of the
+  context to scale beyond the disk capacity of the task manager. **However**, it currently is in an
+  experimental stage and **must not** be enabled for any production use.
+
+Flink also supports `timely stream processing
+<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/time/>`__, which is an
+extension of stateful processing in which chronology is relevant.
+
+:aws:`Amazon MSF <managed-service-apache-flink/>` (:aws:`formerly known as Amazon Kinesis Data
+Analytics
+<blogs/aws/announcing-amazon-managed-service-for-apache-flink-renamed-from-amazon-kinesis-data-analytics/>`)
+is a managed platform for provisioning and operating Flink clusters. It enriches the functionality
+that Flink natively provides by enabling integrations with other AWS services (e.g., CloudWatch,
+Glue Schema Registry, Kinesis, S3, and EC2 VPC). You may deploy your Flink application code to MSF
+as a :wikipedia:`JAR <JAR_(file_format)>` from S3 (setting :awsdocs:`CodeContentType
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-properties-kinesisanalyticsv2-application-applicationcodeconfiguration.html#cfn-kinesisanalyticsv2-application-applicationcodeconfiguration-codecontenttype>`
+to ``ZIPFILE``), which is compatible with :doc:`the archetypal internal deployment tool-chain
+<nativedg:native-aws-mental-model>` at Amazon. For interactive development, MSF provides a
+serverless :awsdocs:`notebook experience <managed-flink/latest/java/how-notebook.html>` based on
+`Apache Zeppelin <https://zeppelin.apache.org/>`__.
+
+In terms of capability and pricing, MSF is considerably more apt than Lambda for stateful stream
+processing. However, in the context of internal development at Amazon, there are additional factors
+that must be considered. Unfortunately, MSF is `unavailable in certain regions
+<https://regions.aws.dev/services/statuses/kinesisanalytics>`__ and is not a launch-blocking service
+in new region builds. Furthermore, although there is :awsdocs:`CloudFormation support
+<AWSCloudFormation/latest/TemplateReference/aws-resource-kinesisanalyticsv2-application.html>` for
+MSF applications, you will be required to :awsdocs:`build your own support
+<managed-flink/latest/java/lambda-cfn-flink.html>` to (re)start an application after it has been
+created or updated. Additionally, applications must have :awsdocs:`maintenance windows
+<managed-flink/latest/java/maintenance.html>`, which is at odds with the goal of designing an
+application that can react to events on demand at all times. Finally, MSF does not support certain
+internal standards for security and operational excellence (e.g., incremental deployment, encryption
+with KMS customer-managed keys). For these reasons, it is difficult to recommend MSF for internal
+use despite its relevant strengths.
+
+
+Amazon EventBridge Pipes
+------------------------
+
+:awsdocs:`Amazon EventBridge Pipes <eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes.html>` is a service that
+enables point-to-point delivery between myriad pairs of :awsdocs:`sources
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-source.html>` and :awsdocs:`targets
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-target.html>`. It provides mechanisms for
+:awsdocs:`enrichment <eventbridge/latest/userguide/pipes-enrichment.html>`, :awsdocs:`filtering
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-event-filtering.html>`, and :awsdocs:`transformations
+<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-input-transformation.html>`. Builders commonly use Lambda
+functions to implement these behaviors today; in supported contexts, a pipe behaves as a zero-code
+replacement.
+
+It is feasible for a pipe to deliver records from a stream to a Lambda function (as an alternative
+to Lambda ESM). However, there are compelling reasons not to do this. Firstly, if an application is
+not otherwise using EventBridge Pipes, then it will introduce an additional service dependency, and
+EventBridge Pipes is `unavailable in some regions
+<https://regions.aws.dev/services/statuses/pipes>`__. Secondly, there are certain features available
+via ESM that are not supported via Pipes (e.g., tumbling windows, S3 as an on-failure destination).
+In absence of a strong incentive to the contrary, builders using Lambda should prefer ESM over
+Pipes.

find this section hard to grok visually, with the bullet list format. I suggest using a table. Here's a suggested approach:


```rst
Flink supports `four distinct API layers
<https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/concepts/overview/>`__ arranged in a hierarchy from highest to lowest level of abstraction:

.. list-table:: **Flink API Layers**
   :widths: 20 80
   :header-rows: 1
   
   * - **API Layer**
     - **Description**
   * - **SQL**
     - `Implementation <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/sql/overview/>`__ 
       of the :aws:`SQL <what-is/sql/>` standard based on `Apache Calcite <https://calcite.apache.org/>`__. 
       Highest level of abstraction.
   * - **Table API**
     - `Declarative DSL <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/table/tableapi/>`__ 
       based on the :wikipedia:`relational model <Relational_model>`. 
       Define tables as schemas and query with relational operators like ``select()``. 
       Interoperable with the SQL layer.
   * - **Core API**
     - Based on the `DataStream object <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/datastream/DataStream.html>`__
       with fundamental building blocks: `sources <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sources>`__, 
       `sinks <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/overview/#data-sinks>`__, 
       and `transforms <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/overview/>`__.
   * - **ProcessFunction**
     - Lowest level of abstraction embedded in the Core API. Exposed via the abstract 
       `ProcessFunction <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-stable/api/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/functions/ProcessFunction.html>`__
       that can `access and manipulate <https://nightlies.apache.org/flink/flink-docs-release-2.0/docs/dev/datastream/operators/process_function/>`__
       primitive elements of a ``DataStream``.
```

I'd also recommend using [anonymous](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/links-references/#anonymous-links) or [named](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/links-references/#named-links) links for all those long URLs to external Apache docs. Probably better to go with anonymous since they all seems to be unique? 1→.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.
     2→
     3→   ** Contributions are always welcome! **
     4→
     5→   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
     6→   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/
     7→
     8→   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
     9→   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
    10→
    11→#########
    12→Messaging
    13→#########
    14→
    15→.. contents::
    16→   :local:
    17→
    18→Recommendation
    19→==============
    20→
    21→.. _event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging:
    22→
    23→Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing
    24→--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    25→
    26→:aws:`Amazon SQS <sqs/>` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via
    27→:wikipedia:`message passing <Message_passing>`. It is a fully managed
    28→offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment
    29→strategies, etc. The basic primitive in SQS is the queue, which is a buffer for
    30→messages. You can retain an indefinite number of queues, and each queue can retain an
    31→indefinite number of messages.
    32→
    33→Many other tools in AWS integrate with SQS natively. An integration is native when it can
    34→transport payloads across service boundaries without any assistance from application code.
    35→Native *producers* deliver messages from a sender to a queue; for example, :awsdocs:`an Amazon
    36→Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic <sns/latest/dg/sns-sqs-as-subscriber.html>` or
    37→:awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge bus
    38→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-automating-using-eventbridge.html>`.
    39→Native *consumers* deliver messages from a queue to a
    40→receiver; for example, :awsdocs:`an AWS Lambda event source mapping
    41→<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventsourcemapping.html>` or :awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge pipe
    42→<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-sqs.html>`. The integration between SQS and EventBridge pipes
    43→is particularly notable in that it enables many additional integrations in turn.
    44→
    45→Best practices
    46→==============
    47→
    48→.. _event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue:
    49→
    50→Prefer standard queues over First-In-First-Out (FIFO) queues
    51→------------------------------------------------------------
    52→
    53→SQS supports :awsdocs:`two flavors
    54→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-queue-types.html>` of queue: standard and FIFO.
    55→
    56→* Standard queues do not enforce any definite limit on transactions per second (TPS). Messages
    57→  may be delivered, received, and removed at any rate. While SQS guarantees a minimum of 120k
    58→  :awsdocs:`in-flight
    59→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-visibility-timeout.html>` messages per queue,
    60→  queues with high throughput may automatically receive a higher limit. Additionally, customers
    61→  can request an increased guaranteed minimum through AWS Support.
    62→
    63→* FIFO queues support :awsdocs:`message de-duplication
    64→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-exactly-once-processing.html>`
    65→  (within a 5-minute interval) and in-order delivery (with :awsdocs:`nuances
    66→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-understanding-logic.html>`). However,
    67→  they sacrifice throughput in exchange; message actions are limited to a combined 300 TPS per
    68→  queue.
    69→
    70→Unfortunately, FIFO queues are prone to becoming bottlenecks. They assign messages to groups,
    71→and those messages are guaranteed to be handled in order. Since newer messages in a group
    72→cannot be received until older messages in that same group have been consumed, it is
    73→infeasible to horizontally scale the processing of any given group. This can cause a backlog
    74→of unprocessed messages in the group. A worst-case scenario can occur in which the size
    75→of that backlog exceeds 120k messages overall (i.e., including messages that are not
    76→in-flight), and :awsdocs:`all other groups are denied service
    77→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/avoid-backlog-with-the-same-message-group-id.html>`.
    78→
    79→FIFO queues cannot guarantee either exactly-once processing or message ordering when errors occur,
    80→or messages move to a dead-letter queue (DLQ). Your business logic should be designed to handle both
    81→duplicate *and* out-of-order messages.
    82→
    83→.. warning:: Some AWS services that integrate with SQS don't support FIFO queues. However, these services may not
    84→   explicitly block you from configuring one, which can lead to unexpected failures at runtime.
    85→   This list includes (**but is not limited to**):
    86→
    87→   * :awsdocs:`Amazon S3 Event Notifications <AmazonS3/latest/dev/NotificationHowTo.html>`
    88→   * :awsdocs:`Auto Scaling Lifecycle Hooks <autoscaling/ec2/userguide/lifecycle-hooks.html>`
    89→   * :awsdocs:`AWS IoT Rule Actions <iot/latest/developerguide/iot-rule-actions.html>`
    90→   * :awsdocs:`AWS Lambda Dead-Letter Queues <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async.html#invocation-dlq>`
    91→
    92→.. _event-consumer-messaging-enable-high-throughput-fifo:
    93→
    94→Enable high throughput on FIFO queues
    95→-------------------------------------
    96→
    97→If you must use FIFO queues, ASBX **strongly encourages** that you enable :awsdocs:`high throughput
    98→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/high-throughput-fifo.html>` for all new development,
    99→and you should *consider* enabling it in your existing applications when it is safe to do so.
   100→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:

#########
Messaging
#########

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendation
==============

.. _event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging:

Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

:aws:`Amazon SQS <sqs/>` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via
:wikipedia:`message passing <Message_passing>`. It is a fully managed
offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment
strategies, etc. The basic primitive in SQS is the queue, which is a buffer for
messages. You can retain an indefinite number of queues, and each queue can retain an
indefinite number of messages.

Many other tools in AWS integrate with SQS natively. An integration is native when it can
transport payloads across service boundaries without any assistance from application code.
Native *producers* deliver messages from a sender to a queue; for example, :awsdocs:`an Amazon
Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic <sns/latest/dg/sns-sqs-as-subscriber.html>` or
:awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge bus
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-automating-using-eventbridge.html>`.
Native *consumers* deliver messages from a queue to a
receiver; for example, :awsdocs:`an AWS Lambda event source mapping
<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventsourcemapping.html>` or :awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge pipe
<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-sqs.html>`. The integration between SQS and EventBridge pipes
is particularly notable in that it enables many additional integrations in turn.

Best practices
==============

.. _event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue:

Prefer standard queues over First-In-First-Out (FIFO) queues
------------------------------------------------------------

SQS supports :awsdocs:`two flavors
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-queue-types.html>` of queue: standard and FIFO.

* Standard queues do not enforce any definite limit on transactions per second (TPS). Messages
  may be delivered, received, and removed at any rate. While SQS guarantees a minimum of 120k
  :awsdocs:`in-flight
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-visibility-timeout.html>` messages per queue,
  queues with high throughput may automatically receive a higher limit. Additionally, customers
  can request an increased guaranteed minimum through AWS Support.

* FIFO queues support :awsdocs:`message de-duplication
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-exactly-once-processing.html>`
  (within a 5-minute interval) and in-order delivery (with :awsdocs:`nuances
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-understanding-logic.html>`). However,
  they sacrifice throughput in exchange; message actions are limited to a combined 300 TPS per
  queue.

Unfortunately, FIFO queues are prone to becoming bottlenecks. They assign messages to groups,
and those messages are guaranteed to be handled in order. Since newer messages in a group
cannot be received until older messages in that same group have been consumed, it is
infeasible to horizontally scale the processing of any given group. This can cause a backlog
of unprocessed messages in the group. A worst-case scenario can occur in which the size
of that backlog exceeds 120k messages overall (i.e., including messages that are not
in-flight), and :awsdocs:`all other groups are denied service
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/avoid-backlog-with-the-same-message-group-id.html>`.

FIFO queues cannot guarantee either exactly-once processing or message ordering when errors occur,
or messages move to a dead-letter queue (DLQ). Your business logic should be designed to handle both
duplicate *and* out-of-order messages.

.. warning:: Some AWS services that integrate with SQS don't support FIFO queues. However, these services may not
   explicitly block you from configuring one, which can lead to unexpected failures at runtime.
   This list includes (**but is not limited to**):

   * :awsdocs:`Amazon S3 Event Notifications <AmazonS3/latest/dev/NotificationHowTo.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`Auto Scaling Lifecycle Hooks <autoscaling/ec2/userguide/lifecycle-hooks.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`AWS IoT Rule Actions <iot/latest/developerguide/iot-rule-actions.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`AWS Lambda Dead-Letter Queues <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async.html#invocation-dlq>`

.. _event-consumer-messaging-enable-high-throughput-fifo:

Enable high throughput on FIFO queues
-------------------------------------

If you must use FIFO queues, ASBX **strongly encourages** that you enable :awsdocs:`high throughput
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/high-throughput-fifo.html>` for all new development,
and you should *consider* enabling it in your existing applications when it is safe to do so.

This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The conversation is summarized below:
Analysis:
Let me chronologically analyze the conversation to capture all key details:

1. **Initial Request**: The user requested creation of an agent to examine documentation changes and validate them against a style guide for BuilderHub documentation. They explicitly mentioned this is a codebase that creates documents that live on BuilderHub.

2. **User's Task List** (Critical user message - not a tool result): The user provided 4 specific tasks:
   - Task 1: Examine the last 100 code reviews to this package and look at the comments left
   - Task 2: Make sure you understand the formatting that is required to make everything look correct
   - Task 3: Make sure you understand how the docs write in the 3rd person
   - Task 4: Make sure you cache the different files and their content, so that you can intelligently link to relevant docs as we make new updates

3. **My Approach**: I created a TODO list to track progress and systematically explored:
   - The codebase structure (/Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES)
   - Documentation organization (developer_guide, web_services, event_consumers, golden_path)
   - Style guide references
   - Code review patterns and common feedback
   - RST formatting requirements
   - Writing style patterns (3rd person)

4. **Key Code Reviews Examined**:
   - CR-213538074: Simple link consistency update
   - CR-213528560: Addressing leftover nits
   - CR-213278257: Adding "Paradigm" section to Challenges
   - CR-212297763: Major review with extensive feedback on Stream Processing documentation

5. **Important Patterns Discovered from CR-212297763**:
   - Use `:awsdocs:` role for AWS documentation links
   - Use `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
   - Headers should be sentence case
   - Line length should be ~100 characters where possible
   - Use `.. note::` directives for important information
   - Use `.. warning::` for critical warnings
   - Tables preferred over bullet lists for complex information
   - Write in second person ("you") not third person (contrary to user's assumption)
   - Use reference labels like `.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda:`
   - Proper heading hierarchy (h2 for main sections, h3 for subsections)

6. **Documentation Structure**:
   - Uses reStructuredText (RST) format
   - Standard copyright header
   - Table of contents with `:local:`
   - Recommendation/Best Practices/Caveats/Alternatives sections
   - Cross-referencing between documents
   - Shared snippets and includes

7. **Style Guide References**:
   - https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/ (mentioned in contribution guide)
   - BuilderHub documentation contribution guide at https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/

8. **Current Work Status**: I was in the process of examining writing style patterns and preparing to cache file content for intelligent linking.

Summary:
1. Primary Request and Intent:
   The user wants me to create an agent that can examine all changes to BuilderHub documentation and validate them against the style guide. The user specifically requested that I:
   - Examine the last 100 code reviews and analyze comments to understand common feedback patterns
   - Understand the formatting requirements for correct display
   - Understand how docs should be written in 3rd person (though evidence suggests 2nd person is actually used)
   - Cache different files and their content to intelligently link to relevant docs when making updates

2. Key Technical Concepts:
   - BuilderHub documentation system
   - reStructuredText (RST) formatting
   - BTDocs-BONES documentation package
   - Code review patterns via CRUX
   - AWS CDK documentation
   - Event-driven architectures (messaging, streaming, orchestration)
   - Golden Path recommendations
   - Cross-document referencing and intersphinx
   - Brazil build system

3. Files and Code Sections:
   - /Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES/btdocs-config.yaml
      - Configuration file defining documentation structure and redirects
      - Defines doc sets: docs_info, event_consumers, developer_guide, golden_path, web_services
   
   - /Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES/developer_guide/contribution-guide.rst
      - Contains reference to style guide at https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/
      - Lists subject matter experts for different technologies
      - Defines contribution expectations and processes
   
   - /Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES/event_consumers/messaging.rst
      - Example of well-formatted documentation
      - Shows proper use of RST directives, headers, and linking patterns
      ```rst
      .. _event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging:
      
      Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing
      --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
      
      :aws:`Amazon SQS <sqs/>` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via
      :wikipedia:`message passing <Message_passing>`.
      ```

   - /Volumes/workplace/BuilderHub/GPDocs/src/BTDocs-BONES/event_consumers/stream-processing.rst
      - New documentation file analyzed in CR-212297763
      - Shows common formatting issues and corrections needed

4. Errors and fixes:
   - Incorrect heading hierarchy: Fixed by ensuring h2 for main sections (==) and h3 for subsections (--)
   - Improper link formatting: Fixed by using `:awsdocs:` and `:wikipedia:` roles instead of raw URLs
   - Writing style issues: Changed from "builders" and "one may" to "you" (second person)
   - Line length violations: Fixed by breaking long lines at ~100 characters
   - Missing reference labels: Added labels like `.. _event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda:`
   - Bullet lists for complex data: Converted to tables per reviewer feedback

5. Problem Solving:
   - Discovered the actual style guide location through contribution guide
   - Identified common review patterns by examining multiple CRs
   - Found that documentation actually uses 2nd person ("you") not 3rd person as user assumed
   - Recognized RST formatting patterns and directives
   - Understood the importance of consistent linking patterns

6. All user messages:

   - "task list to complete to make sure you know you have all the context you need. 1) examine the last 100 code reviews to this package and look at the comments left, you can find the link to the crs in the commit messages. 2) make sure you understand the formatting that is required to make everything look correct. 3) make sure you understand how the docs write in the 3rd person 4) make sure you cache the different files and their content, so that you can intelligently link to relevant docs as we make new updates"

7. Pending Tasks:
   - Create an agent/tool to validate docs against style guide (main deliverable)
   - Cache file content for intelligent linking (task 4 from user)

   I was analyzing the writing style patterns in the documentation, specifically looking for examples of 3rd person writing as requested by the user. I had just completed examining formatting requirements and was using grep to search for patterns like "you should/can/must/may/need" to understand the actual writing style used in the documentation.

9. Optional Next Step:
   The next step would be to complete task 4 by caching important documentation files and their content, then proceed to create the validation agent. This directly aligns with the user's explicit request: "make sure you cache the different files and their content, so that you can intelligently link to relevant docs as we make new updates" and leads to the main deliverable of creating "a agent that can examine all changes to these docs, and make sure if follows the style guide.".

.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

########################
Building event consumers
########################

.. contents::
   :local:

Event consumers are applications that process events or messages from various sources such as event
buses, queues, or streams. They are a fundamental component of
:aws:`event-driven architectures <event-driven-architecture/>`, enabling systems to react to
changes, process data asynchronously, and maintain loose coupling between services.

This topic provides |asbx| recommendations for building robust,
scalable, and maintainable event consumer applications at Amazon. Our goal is to help builders make
informed decisions about tools, technologies, and architectural patterns when implementing
event-driven solutions.

Whether you're building a new event consumer application or evolving an existing one, these
recommendations provide you with best practice guidance and help you to avoid
common pitfalls.

Understanding the challenges
============================

Event-driven architectures present unique challenges that differ significantly from traditional
request-response patterns. Before diving into specific recommendations, we recommend reviewing
:doc:`challenges`, which explores key technical considerations including:

* Fair queuing across multiple sources
* Message filtering strategies
* Building resilient event processing pipelines
* Maintaining data consistency
* Implementing idempotent processing
* Managing message sequencing
* Schema management and validation
* Operational visibility and monitoring
* Deployment safety
* Compliance and security considerations

Understanding these challenges will help you make better architectural decisions when designing
your event consumer applications.

Getting started
===============

.. note::

   ASBX plans to deliver an event consumer source application that will be available in
   |bhcreate|_. This source application will demonstrate best practices for implementing event
   consumers using our recommended tools and technologies.

   While the source application is not yet available, you can still use the recommendations here to
   guide your implementation. We'll update this section when the source application is ready for
   use.

Feedback
========

If you have any feedback on the recommendations made in this document, please
use the :guilabel:`Provide feedback` link at the bottom of the page to create
an issue.

We intend for this to be a living document that is updated as we, as a company,
learn about sharp edges and evolving best practices. Your feedback is invaluable
in helping us understand where our recommendations need further attention and will directly
influence future updates to these guidelines.

Recommendations inventory
=========================

This section provides a quick glance of ASBX recommendations that are specific to the event consumer
application type (as opposed to general recommendations for tooling throughout the software
development life cycle (SDLC) at Amazon).

.. note:: The ASBX recommendations for event consumer application types are under active
   development (with many more coming soon), and this content will expand and evolve over time.
   We are continuously working with service teams and subject matter experts to validate and refine
   these recommendations based on real-world usage patterns and emerging best practices.

Tooling recommendations
-----------------------

.. include:: ../shared_snippets/tooling-recommendations-categories.txt

.. Copyright © 2023, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#####################
Building web services
#####################

.. contents::
   :local:

.. meta::
   :description: Building web services.

.. _golden-path-recommendations-for-web-services:

Web services remain a popular application choice and are a key component of Service Oriented
Architecture (SOA) and microservices. Web services continue to stand the test of time because they
offer a highly distributed, language agnostic, lightweight, and modular API model that can easily
evolve as application requirements change. Moreover, there are a large amount of resources that are
invested at Amazon for building and maintaining highly available services. It is very likely that
web services will continue to be used to build next generation applications and services.

.. list-table::
   :header-rows: 1

   * - If you are building...
     - See...

   * - Web services in Native AWS
     - 🏆 :doc:`golden-path-lambda`

       🏆 :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`

       :doc:`cdk-howto-ec2`


   * - Web services in PROD/CORP
     - :doc:`develop-prod-corp-web-services`

Which compute target should I use?
==================================

When choosing a compute target for a new service, we strongly recommend that you select the platform
that allows you to meet customer needs while owning the smallest amount of infrastructure possible.
By using the right level of abstraction, you can spend more time making your customers' lives better
and focus on writing the code of your application instead of spending time maintaining a vast array
of resources that require long-term maintenance.

For web services, we first recommend Lambda, followed by ECS Fargate. The right option for your
new web service can likely be determined by your application's requirements:

.. include:: ../shared/request-reply-requirements-table.txt

If your application has requirements that cannot be met by Lambda or ECS Fargate, including special
hardware requirements, new region availability requirements, or the need to avoid circular
dependencies, we recommend EC2. For more information, see :doc:`webservices:cdk-howto-ec2`.

Golden Path recommendations for web services
============================================

There are many factors to consider when building and deploying web services for production. The
Golden Path program publishes many recommendations that generally provide the best opportunity for
creating successful services and applications given the vast options and tooling available from AWS
and BuilderTools. The recommendations are reviewed and updated on a regular basis to ensure they
remain technically accurate and current.

* :doc:`goldenpath:index`

* 🏆 :doc:`golden-path-lambda`: A set of recommendations and best practices to consider when
  deploying web services on Lambda.

* 🏆 :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`: A set of recommendations and best practices to consider
  when deploying web services on ECS and Fargate.

Web service frameworks
======================

Coral and Smithy are the web service frameworks that are being used at scale across many teams
at Amazon and AWS. These frameworks allow teams to focus on creating business logic rather
than managing low-level web service technologies or extending existing frameworks to work with
AWS tools.

* :wiki:`Coral`: Coral is a proprietary web service framework for creating and hosting RPC and REST
  services. Coral includes both server-side frameworks and automatic client code generation in a
  number of popular languages. Coral includes a rich set of features, which include tools for
  developing and deploying services, serialization, throttling, metrics, management, security, and
  more.

* :wiki:`Smithy`: Smithy is an Interface Definition Language (IDL) and set of tools that allows
  developers to build clients and servers in multiple languages. Smithy models define a service as a
  collection of resources, operations, and shapes. A Smithy model enables API providers to generate
  clients and servers in various programming languages, API documentation, test automation, and
  example code. Although Coral includes its own IDL, Smithy is an evolution of that model and Smithy
  is now the preferred way to model web services.


Web service tutorials
=====================

The quickest way to get started standing up web services is to use |bhcreate|_. In particular,
|bhcreate| includes |bhcreate-srcapps|_ that provide the necessary setup and integration code
required to develop, build, and deploy web services. The following tutorials make use of the
|bhcreate-srcapps| and are recommended if you are new to development at AWS.

* :doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda`: This tutorial steps through creating a
  :bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Lambda <cle-java-lambda>` application using |bhcreate|. This
  application can be used as a starting point for the 🏆 :doc:`golden-path-lambda`.

* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs`: This tutorial steps through creating a :bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral
  Service on Fargate <coral-fargate>` application using |bhcreate| and also includes additional
  steps that demonstrate common development and deployment tasks. This application can be used as a
  starting point for the 🏆 :doc:`golden-path-ecs-fargate`.

.. toctree::
   :hidden:
   :titlesonly:

   🏆 Lambda Golden Path (web service) <golden-path-lambda>
   🏆 ECS-Fargate Golden Path (web service) <golden-path-ecs-fargate>
   cdk-howto-ec2
   develop-prod-corp-web-services

.. Copyright © 2024, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://builderhub.corp.amazon.com/docs/contributing.html

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

##############################
🏆 Golden Path recommendations
##############################

.. contents::
   :local:

The Golden Path process
=======================

The purpose of the Golden Path program is to make continuous improvements to the development
workflow for supported application types (e.g. :doc:`webservices:golden-path-lambda`).

This is done by producing opinionated best practice tooling, architecture, and configuration
recommendations for the end-to-end workflow. These recommendations are :doc:`vetted widely
<reviewers>` (Builder Tools, AWS, SDO, service teams, security, etc).

We then build a :bhcreate:`source application <clone/cle-java-lambda-peru>` that follows as many of
the Golden Path recommendations as current automation allows, to make it easy to get started on the
current best practice.

Anything that cannot be automated, gaps, or opportunities to improve the toolchain, are then
documented and tracked by the Golden Path program. We drive technical agreement across partner
teams to find a way to eliminate undifferentiated work.

The outcome we seek with the Golden Paths is that teams spend time only on their differentiated
business logic and nothing else.

.. _golden-path-architecture:

Golden Path architecture
========================

A *Golden Path architecture* is a set of recommended tools for a given application
type. It includes the :doc:`current best choices <learn:choosing-tools>`
across personal development, deployment infrastructure, runtime infrastructure,
application operations, and application framework that have been vetted for
security, safety, and operational excellence by domain experts. Builder Tools
teams continuously review these recommendations and update them every 6 months
as tooling evolve.

Because every compute platform brings with it a different set of best practices,
we provide Golden Path architecture recommendations based on target compute platform.

.. note:: See :doc:`learn:choosing-compute-platform` for recommendations about choosing a compute
   platform based on your org (AWS/SDO) and the needs of your application or service.

As it is hard to provide best practices that are appropriate or sufficient
for all cases, we prioritize certain types of software over others. Each golden
path program defines a single application type and discusses the best tools
and options for each area and stage in your development, deployment, and operation
cycle.

Available Golden Paths
======================

The following Golden Paths are available. If your desired application type is not listed here, see
:doc:`other`.

For more information, see :doc:`apptypes:index`.

.. contents::
   :local:

.. list-table::
   :header-rows: 1

   * - Application type
     - Recommendations

   * - Web services
     - :doc:`web-services`

   * - Generative AI
     - 🏆 :doc:`genai:golden-path-genai`

   * - Workflow orchestration
     - 🏆 :doc:`workfloworchestration:golden-path-sdo`

##########################
Native AWS Developer Guide
##########################

.. contents::
   :local:

.. the following just puts a link in the left-hand ToC to this guide (so it's easy to get to again)
.. toctree::
   :titlesonly:
   :hidden:

   Welcome <self>


What is Native AWS?
===================

*Native AWS* is the idea that we should give Amazon developers the ability to use AWS more like AWS
customers. That Builder Tools will get out of the way and allow you to use new AWS services when
they launch instead of waiting behind updates to internal tools.

We started on this path by opening up AWS compute platforms: Lambda, ECS, and EC2. This enables
teams to run services in an account they control and use any AWS service they wish.

Because the internal developer tools are :doc:`more mature than the Code Suite
<learn:choosing-tools>`, we began by enabling :doc:`pipelines:index` to orchestrate deployments to
Native AWS compute, while continuing to use Pipelines, :doc:`Brazil <brazil:index>`, and
:doc:`gitfarm:index`.


In this guide
=============

   :titlesonly:

==================================

    12→Messaging

    14→
    15→.. contents::
    16→   :local:
    17→
    18→Recommendation
    19→==============
    20→
    21→.. _event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging:
    22→
    23→Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing
    24→--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    25→
    26→:aws:`Amazon SQS <sqs/>` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via
    27→:wikipedia:`message passing <Message_passing>`. It is a fully managed
    28→offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment
    29→strategies, etc. The basic primitive in SQS is the queue, which is a buffer for
    30→messages. You can retain an indefinite number of queues, and each queue can retain an
    31→indefinite number of messages.
    32→
    33→Many other tools in AWS integrate with SQS natively. An integration is native when it can
    34→transport payloads across service boundaries without any assistance from application code.
    35→Native *producers* deliver messages from a sender to a queue; for example, :awsdocs:`an Amazon
    36→Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic <sns/latest/dg/sns-sqs-as-subscriber.html>` or
    37→:awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge bus
    38→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-automating-using-eventbridge.html>`.
    39→Native *consumers* deliver messages from a queue to a
    40→receiver; for example, :awsdocs:`an AWS Lambda event source mapping
    41→<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventsourcemapping.html>` or :awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge pipe
    42→<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-sqs.html>`. The integration between SQS and EventBridge pipes
    43→is particularly notable in that it enables many additional integrations in turn.
    44→
    45→Best practices
    46→==============
    47→
    48→.. _event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue:
    49→
    50→Prefer standard queues over First-In-First-Out (FIFO) queues
    51→------------------------------------------------------------
    52→
    53→SQS supports :awsdocs:`two flavors
    54→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-queue-types.html>` of queue: standard and FIFO.
    55→
    56→* Standard queues do not enforce any definite limit on transactions per second (TPS). Messages
    57→  may be delivered, received, and removed at any rate. While SQS guarantees a minimum of 120k
    58→  :awsdocs:`in-flight
    59→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-visibility-timeout.html>` messages per queue,
    60→  queues with high throughput may automatically receive a higher limit. Additionally, customers
    61→  can request an increased guaranteed minimum through AWS Support.
    62→
    63→* FIFO queues support :awsdocs:`message de-duplication
    64→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-exactly-once-processing.html>`
    65→  (within a 5-minute interval) and in-order delivery (with :awsdocs:`nuances
    66→  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-understanding-logic.html>`). However,
    67→  they sacrifice throughput in exchange; message actions are limited to a combined 300 TPS per
    68→  queue.
    69→
    70→Unfortunately, FIFO queues are prone to becoming bottlenecks. They assign messages to groups,
    71→and those messages are guaranteed to be handled in order. Since newer messages in a group
    72→cannot be received until older messages in that same group have been consumed, it is
    73→infeasible to horizontally scale the processing of any given group. This can cause a backlog
    74→of unprocessed messages in the group. A worst-case scenario can occur in which the size
    75→of that backlog exceeds 120k messages overall (i.e., including messages that are not
    76→in-flight), and :awsdocs:`all other groups are denied service
    77→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/avoid-backlog-with-the-same-message-group-id.html>`.
    78→
    79→FIFO queues cannot guarantee either exactly-once processing or message ordering when errors occur,
    80→or messages move to a dead-letter queue (DLQ). Your business logic should be designed to handle both
    81→duplicate *and* out-of-order messages.
    82→
    83→.. warning:: Some AWS services that integrate with SQS don't support FIFO queues. However, these services may not
    84→   explicitly block you from configuring one, which can lead to unexpected failures at runtime.
    85→   This list includes (**but is not limited to**):
    86→
    87→   * :awsdocs:`Amazon S3 Event Notifications <AmazonS3/latest/dev/NotificationHowTo.html>`
    88→   * :awsdocs:`Auto Scaling Lifecycle Hooks <autoscaling/ec2/userguide/lifecycle-hooks.html>`
    89→   * :awsdocs:`AWS IoT Rule Actions <iot/latest/developerguide/iot-rule-actions.html>`
    90→   * :awsdocs:`AWS Lambda Dead-Letter Queues <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async.html#invocation-dlq>`
    91→
    92→.. _event-consumer-messaging-enable-high-throughput-fifo:
    93→
    94→Enable high throughput on FIFO queues
    95→-------------------------------------
    96→
    97→If you must use FIFO queues, ASBX **strongly encourages** that you enable :awsdocs:`high throughput
    98→<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/high-throughput-fifo.html>` for all new development,
    99→and you should *consider* enabling it in your existing applications when it is safe to do so.

file.content:
.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#########
Messaging
#########

.. contents::
   :local:

Recommendation
==============

.. _event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging:

Prefer Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) for messaging with stateless processing
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

:aws:`Amazon SQS <sqs/>` facilitates coordination between dispersed processes via
:wikipedia:`message passing <Message_passing>`. It is a fully managed
offering; you don't need to specify hardware requirements, maintenance windows, deployment
strategies, etc. The basic primitive in SQS is the queue, which is a buffer for
messages. You can retain an indefinite number of queues, and each queue can retain an
indefinite number of messages.

Many other tools in AWS integrate with SQS natively. An integration is native when it can
transport payloads across service boundaries without any assistance from application code.
Native *producers* deliver messages from a sender to a queue; for example, :awsdocs:`an Amazon
Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic <sns/latest/dg/sns-sqs-as-subscriber.html>` or
:awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge bus
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-automating-using-eventbridge.html>`.
Native *consumers* deliver messages from a queue to a
receiver; for example, :awsdocs:`an AWS Lambda event source mapping
<lambda/latest/dg/invocation-eventsourcemapping.html>` or :awsdocs:`an Amazon EventBridge pipe
<eventbridge/latest/userguide/eb-pipes-sqs.html>`. The integration between SQS and EventBridge pipes
is particularly notable in that it enables many additional integrations in turn.

Best practices
==============

.. _event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue:

Prefer standard queues over First-In-First-Out (FIFO) queues
------------------------------------------------------------

SQS supports :awsdocs:`two flavors
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-queue-types.html>` of queue: standard and FIFO.

* Standard queues do not enforce any definite limit on transactions per second (TPS). Messages
  may be delivered, received, and removed at any rate. While SQS guarantees a minimum of 120k
  :awsdocs:`in-flight
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-visibility-timeout.html>` messages per queue,
  queues with high throughput may automatically receive a higher limit. Additionally, customers
  can request an increased guaranteed minimum through AWS Support.

* FIFO queues support :awsdocs:`message de-duplication
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-exactly-once-processing.html>`
  (within a 5-minute interval) and in-order delivery (with :awsdocs:`nuances
  <AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/FIFO-queues-understanding-logic.html>`). However,
  they sacrifice throughput in exchange; message actions are limited to a combined 300 TPS per
  queue.

Unfortunately, FIFO queues are prone to becoming bottlenecks. They assign messages to groups,
and those messages are guaranteed to be handled in order. Since newer messages in a group
cannot be received until older messages in that same group have been consumed, it is
infeasible to horizontally scale the processing of any given group. This can cause a backlog
of unprocessed messages in the group. A worst-case scenario can occur in which the size
of that backlog exceeds 120k messages overall (i.e., including messages that are not
in-flight), and :awsdocs:`all other groups are denied service
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/avoid-backlog-with-the-same-message-group-id.html>`.

FIFO queues cannot guarantee either exactly-once processing or message ordering when errors occur,
or messages move to a dead-letter queue (DLQ). Your business logic should be designed to handle both
duplicate *and* out-of-order messages.

.. warning:: Some AWS services that integrate with SQS don't support FIFO queues. However, these services may not
   explicitly block you from configuring one, which can lead to unexpected failures at runtime.
   This list includes (**but is not limited to**):

   * :awsdocs:`Amazon S3 Event Notifications <AmazonS3/latest/dev/NotificationHowTo.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`Auto Scaling Lifecycle Hooks <autoscaling/ec2/userguide/lifecycle-hooks.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`AWS IoT Rule Actions <iot/latest/developerguide/iot-rule-actions.html>`
   * :awsdocs:`AWS Lambda Dead-Letter Queues <lambda/latest/dg/invocation-async.html#invocation-dlq>`

.. _event-consumer-messaging-enable-high-throughput-fifo:

Enable high throughput on FIFO queues
-------------------------------------

If you must use FIFO queues, ASBX **strongly encourages** that you enable :awsdocs:`high throughput
<AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/high-throughput-fifo.html>` for all new development,
and you should *consider* enabling it in your existing applications when it is safe to do so.

################################
Lambda Golden Path (web service)
################################

.. meta::
   :description: Lambda Golden Path (Web Service)

.. contents::
   :depth: 2
   :local:

.. toctree::
   :hidden:

   Infrastructure management <golden-path-iac>
   Scaffolding resources <golden-path-scaffolding>
   Dependency management <golden-path-dependency-management>
   CloudFormation stack management <golden-path-cloudformation-stack-management>
   VPC <golden-path-vpc>
   Load balancer <golden-path-lambda-load-balancer>
   DNS <golden-path-dns>
   Certificate management <golden-path-certificate-management>
   PROD/CORP connectivity <golden-path-corp-prod-connectivity>
   Service framework <golden-path-lambda-service-framework>
   Function configuration <golden-path-lambda-function-configuration>
   Configuration management <golden-path-configuration-management>
   Authentication and authorization <golden-path-lambda-auth>
   Production deployment <golden-path-lambda-production-deployment>
   Local development <golden-path-lambda-local-development>
   Integration testing <golden-path-integration-testing>
   Load, fuzz, and canary testing <golden-path-other-testing>
   Logging <golden-path-lambda-logging>
   Monitoring and alarms <golden-path-lambda-monitoring-alarms>
   Dashboards <golden-path-dashboards>
   Troubleshooting <golden-path-lambda-troubleshooting>

Overview
========

:aws:`AWS Lambda <lambda>` is the most abstract compute platform to date. It
allows developers to build and scale easily without having to worry about the
burden of maintaining the underlying platforms. The uniqueness of Lambda's
Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) model and gaps of existing services make it
challenging for developers who develop new applications or migrate existing ones
from other platforms. Lambda golden path guide provides recommendations for
aspects that you should consider when designing and building your serverless
applications.

With Lambda, you can run code for virtually any type of application or back-end
service. For the purpose of this article, we target a Lambda application with the
following profile:

* A request/response service operating at 1,000 TPS or less. By default, Lambda
  supports up to 1,000 concurrent executions. Concurrent executions are related to
  TPS, `but they are not the same`__. AWS Premium Support can increase this
  :awsdocs:`limit <lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-limits.html>`
  to an extent and with turnaround time. The recommendations in this guide have not
  been vetted for workloads exceeding 1,000 TPS.

  .. __: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/compute/understanding-aws-lambdas-invoke-throttle-limits/
* The service supports service-to-service authentication and commits to an
  availability level of 99.95% uptime.

Many recommendations still apply to other Lambda application types although
they are not the focus of this topic.

Getting started
===============

If you are creating a new application, or if you just want to experiment with running a web service
on Lambda in a low-risk environment, we recommend that you start with the
:bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Lambda <cle-java-lambda>` sample application on |bhcreate|,
which provides as many of the Golden Path recommendations as possible (those that are supported by
automation) out of the box.

For detailed instructions on creating and deploying the sample application, see the
:doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda` tutorial.

Feedback
========

If you have any feedback on the recommendations made in this document, please
use the :guilabel:`Provide feedback` link at the bottom of the page to create
an issue.

We intend for this to be a living document that is updated as we, as a company,
learn about sharp edges and evolving best practices. Your feedback is invaluable
in helping us understand where our recommendations need further attention.

General advice
