#####################################
ECS-Fargate Golden Path (web service)
#####################################

.. meta::
   :description: ECS-Fargate Golden Path

.. contents::
   :depth: 2
   :local:

.. toctree::
   :hidden:

   Language choice <golden-path-ecs-fargate-language-choice>
   Infrastructure as code <golden-path-ecs-fargate-iac>
   Scaffolding resources <golden-path-ecs-fargate-scaffolding-resources>
   Account management <golden-path-ecs-fargate-account-management>
   Task and container organization <golden-path-ecs-fargate-container-organization>
   Consuming sidecars <golden-path-ecs-fargate-sidecars>
   VPC configuration and management <golden-path-ecs-fargate-vpc>
   Autoscaling <golden-path-ecs-fargate-autoscaling>
   DNS management <golden-path-ecs-fargate-dns-management>
   Load balancer <golden-path-ecs-fargate-load-balancer>
   Certificate management <golden-path-ecs-fargate-certificate-management>
   Production deployment <golden-path-ecs-fargate-deployment>
   Prod/Corp connectivity <golden-path-ecs-fargate-prod-corp-connectivity>
   Service dependencies <golden-path-ecs-fargate-service-dependencies>
   Service framework <golden-path-ecs-fargate-service-framework>
   Authentication and authorization <golden-path-ecs-fargate-auth>
   Local development <golden-path-ecs-fargate-local-development>
   Integration testing <golden-path-ecs-fargate-integration-testing>
   Load, fuzz, and canary testing <golden-path-ecs-fargate-load-fuzz-canary-testing>
   Logging <golden-path-ecs-fargate-logging>
   Metrics <golden-path-ecs-fargate-metrics>
   Observability <golden-path-ecs-fargate-observability>
   Dashboards <golden-path-ecs-fargate-dashboards>
   AZ Recovery <golden-path-ecs-fargate-az-recovery>


Overview
========

:aws:`AWS Elastic Container Service <ecs>` and :aws:`Fargate <fargate>` provide a managed way to
containerize your workload while reducing your total burden of infrastructure ownership. They
provide additional flexibility over :doc:`AWS Lambda <golden-path-lambda>` at the expense of
slightly higher operational burden, such as ensuring your container image is up-to-date. Even so,
the managed infrastructure provides an intermediate level of abstraction compared to running raw EC2
instances and is an attractive alternative when AWS Lambda cannot be used for your application.

ECS-Fargate is part of the :aws:`Amazon Compute SLA <compute/sla>`. It commits to 99.99%
availability and specifies :awsdocs:`service limits by concurrent task count
<AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/service-quotas.html>`. For the purpose of this article, we target
an application with the following profile:

* Request/reply service operating from 1 TPS to tens of thousands of TPS.
* The service supports both service-to-service and human-to-service authentication, and commits to
  an availability level of 99.5% uptime or higher.

.. note:: These are target values for an application based on the architecture described in this
   article. The link between TPS and concurrent task count will largely depend on workload. If
   you're planning an application that exceeds these values, start with these recommendations and
   :wiki:`sign up for office hours with ECS <EC2/Project_Madison/OfficeHoursV2>`.

The recommendations that follow may apply for other containerized workloads (such as scheduled tasks
using AWS Batch), but those alternatives are not the focus of this program.

If you are building a new service, start a security review early to discuss your plans and get
feedback. AWS teams can begin with `AppSec <https://appsec.corp.amazon.com/>`__ and SDO teams should
use `Amazon Security Reviews (ASR) <https://asr.security.amazon.dev/>`__.

Getting started
===============

If you are creating a new application, or if you just want to experiment with running a web service
on Fargate in a low-risk environment, we recommend that you start with the
:bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Fargate (AWS employees) <coral-fargate>` or
:bhcreate-srcapp:`Coral Service on Fargate (SDO employees) <coral-fargate-sdo>` sample application
on |bhcreate|, which provides as many of the Golden Path recommendations as possible (those that are
supported by automation) out of the box.

For detailed instructions on creating and deploying the sample application, see the
:doc:`nativedg:hello-world-ecs` tutorial, which includes additional steps that demonstrate common
development and deployment tasks.

Feedback
========

If you have any feedback on the recommendations made in this document, please use the
:guilabel:`Provide feedback` link at the bottom of the page to create an issue.

file.content:
.. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.

   ** Contributions are always welcome! **

   For information about editing or updating this file, see:
   https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/

   For Builder Tools' writing, formatting and style guidelines, see:
   https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/

#################################
Challenges facing event consumers
#################################

.. contents::
   :local:

Event-driven architectures present unique challenges that differ significantly from traditional
request-response patterns. As a builder at Amazon, understanding these challenges is crucial for
designing robust and scalable event consumer applications.

This topic explores the key technical
considerations you'll encounter when building event consumers, from ensuring fair resource
allocation across multiple sources to maintaining data consistency and operational visibility.
Whether you're developing a new event consumer or evolving an existing one, these challenges
represent common pitfalls and architectural decisions that can significantly impact your
application's reliability, performance, and maintainability. By examining each challenge in detail,
you'll be better equipped to make informed design choices and implement effective solutions that
align with Amazon's engineering best practices.

Paradigm
========

The tools that you use will depend largely on whether or not events may be processed discretely.
When your system receives an event *E*, should it be able to process that event without knowledge
(or :wikipedia:`state <State_(computer_science)>`) concerning prior events *E - 1*, *E - 2*, and so on?

While a stateless system might simply validate, transform, or route individual messages one at a time, a
stateful system would be needed for operations like calculating running averages, detecting
patterns across multiple events, or maintaining aggregates over time windows, as these all require
persistent context about previous events.

You should usually prefer **streaming** as a paradigm for systems that require stateful processing
and **messaging** otherwise.

Fair queuing
============

:wikipedia:`Fair queuing <Fair_queuing>` is the need for each **flow** in a system to receive an
equitable degree of service.

Suppose that a system processes work from *N* discrete sources (e.g., queues, accounts) and that
certain sources produce more work than others. The system must guarantee that :awsdocs:`noisy
neighbors <wellarchitected/latest/saas-lens/noisy-neighbor.html>` cannot :wikipedia:`deny service
<Denial-of-service_attack>` to other sources; however, your system should also try to minimize its
idle capacity.

An adequate solution must balance these two concerns.

Message filtering
=================

In some schemes (e.g., :wikipedia:`PubSub <Publish%E2%80%93subscribe_pattern>`), 
a consumer may be interested only in a subset of the messages that are broadcast by the producer(s). 
Irrelevant messages add an undue burden on the consumer, so you should consider **filtering** them.

In order to minimize costs and optimize performance, you should filter on **ingress**. However,
this is not always feasible to implement. Some services do not natively support 
filtering; others may support filtering by **message attribute** (i.e., metadata), but not by 
**payload**.

Fortunately, zero-code integrations between offerings are increasingly available at AWS. When
support in one offering for filtering is not sufficiently robust, it is often possible to combine
it with another (albeit at cost).

Resilience
==========

The flow of traffic through an event consumer is often compared to water through pipework;
continuing with that analogy, you need to prepare for the occasional clog.

content.text: Finally, let me create a practical reference guide for making intelligent cross-references when adding new content:

input.content:
# Intelligent Cross-Reference Guide for BTDocs-BONES

## Overview

This guide provides a systematic approach to identifying and creating meaningful cross-references when adding or updating documentation in the BTDocs-BONES package. Use this when you need to ensure new content is properly integrated with existing documentation.

## Documentation Structure Quick Reference

### Primary Documentation Sections
- **event_consumers/**: ASBX recommendations for event-driven applications
- **web_services/**: Golden Path recommendations for web services (Lambda, ECS Fargate, EC2)  
- **golden_path/**: Meta-documentation about Golden Path program
- **developer_guide/**: Native AWS developer tutorials and how-to guides

## Cross-Reference Decision Matrix

### When Adding Event Consumer Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| SQS messaging patterns | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Lambda SQS integration |
| SQS messaging patterns | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Practical SQS implementation |
| Kinesis streaming | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Step Functions orchestration | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | ECS workflow integration |
| Event processing challenges | All golden path docs | `:doc:` | How golden paths address challenges |

### When Adding Web Service Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda recommendations | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Lambda recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| ECS Fargate recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-ecs.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| Infrastructure as Code | `developer_guide/concept-infra-as-code.rst` | `:doc:` | IaC concepts and patterns |
| VPC configuration | `developer_guide/best-practices-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Detailed VPC best practices |
| DNS management | `developer_guide/dns-strategy.rst` | `:doc:` | DNS strategy and implementation |
| Monitoring/Observability | `developer_guide/cdk-monitoring.rst` | `:doc:` | CDK monitoring implementation |

### When Adding Developer Guide Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| ECS tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| CDK best practices | Related golden path files | `:doc:` | Implementation of recommendations |
| Testing with SAM | `web_services/golden-path-lambda-local-development.rst` | `:doc:` | Local development patterns |
| VPC how-tos | `web_services/golden-path-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path VPC recommendations |

## Reference Label Patterns

### Event Consumers
- `event-consumer-{topic}-{specific-recommendation}`
- Examples: `event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue`, `event-consumer-streaming-prefer-efo`

### Web Services Golden Path
- `golden-path-recommendation-{platform}-{topic}-{action}`
- Examples: `golden-path-recommendation-lambda-framework-use-coral-lambda-endpoint`

### Developer Guide
- Tutorial sections: `hello-{platform}-{section}`
- How-to guides: `{topic}-{specific-action}`
- Examples: `hello-ecs-create-service`, `sam-test-lambda-function-individually`

## Common Cross-Reference Scenarios

### Scenario 1: Adding New Event Consumer Recommendation

**Example**: Adding guidance on AWS EventBridge

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
See also:
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda` for Lambda integration patterns
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate` for container-based event consumers
* :ref:`event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue` for queue-based alternatives
```

### Scenario 2: Adding New Golden Path Component

**Example**: Adding security scanning recommendations

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
Implementation examples:
* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-lambda-cdk` demonstrates security scanning integration
* :doc:`developer_guide/best-practices` covers security best practices

Related recommendations:
* :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-lambda-auth-patterns` for authentication
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-certificate-management` for TLS configuration
```

### Scenario 3: Adding New Tutorial or How-To

**Example**: New CDK construct tutorial

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
This tutorial demonstrates:
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-iac` infrastructure recommendations
* :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-{relevant-label}` implementation

Prerequisites:
* Complete :doc:`getting-started-cdk` first
* Review :doc:`concepts` for background
```

## Quality Checklist

When adding cross-references, ensure:

- [ ] **Bidirectional linking**: If A references B, consider if B should reference A
- [ ] **Contextual relevance**: Reference provides clear value to the reader
- [ ] **Correct syntax**: Use `:doc:`, `:ref:`, or external link formats appropriately  
- [ ] **Reference label exists**: Verify target labels exist before using `:ref:`
- [ ] **Path accuracy**: Ensure file paths are correct for `:doc:` references
- [ ] **Logical flow**: References enhance understanding rather than distract

## Anti-Patterns to Avoid

1. **Over-linking**: Don't reference every tangentially related document
2. **Circular references**: Avoid A→B→A reference chains without clear purpose
3. **Broken references**: Always verify reference targets exist
4. **Context-free links**: Provide context for why the reader should follow the link
5. **Duplicate information**: Reference rather than repeat detailed information

## Testing Cross-References

Before publishing:

1. **Build test**: Ensure all `:doc:` and `:ref:` resolve correctly
2. **Reader perspective**: Follow your own cross-references to verify they add value
3. **Logical flow**: Check that references support the narrative rather than interrupt it

## Templates for Common Cross-References

### Referencing Golden Path from Tutorial
```rst
This tutorial implements the recommendations from :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda`,
specifically following the :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-lambda-framework-use-coral-lambda-endpoint`
guidance for service framework selection.
```

### Referencing Tutorial from Golden Path  
```rst
For a complete implementation example, see the :doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda` tutorial,
which demonstrates these recommendations in practice.
```

### Referencing Best Practices from Implementation
```rst
For detailed guidance on VPC configuration, see :doc:`developer_guide/best-practices-vpc`.
This implementation follows the :ref:`vpc-security-recommendations` pattern.
```

### Cross-Section References (Event Consumers ↔ Web Services)
```rst
Event consumers often need to expose management APIs. For web service patterns,
see :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda` or :doc:`web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate`
depending on your compute requirements.
```

## Maintenance Notes

- **Regular audits**: Periodically check for broken references
- **Content updates**: When updating referenced content, check incoming references  
- **New content integration**: Use this guide when adding any new documentation
- **Reference consolidation**: Look for opportunities to reduce redundant cross-references

## Documentation Structure Quick Reference

### Primary Documentation Sections
- **event_consumers/**: ASBX recommendations for event-driven applications
- **web_services/**: Golden Path recommendations for web services (Lambda, ECS Fargate, EC2)  
- **golden_path/**: Meta-documentation about Golden Path program
- **developer_guide/**: Native AWS developer tutorials and how-to guides

## Cross-Reference Decision Matrix

### When Adding Event Consumer Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| SQS messaging patterns | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Lambda SQS integration |
| SQS messaging patterns | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Practical SQS implementation |
| Kinesis streaming | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Step Functions orchestration | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | ECS workflow integration |
| Event processing challenges | All golden path docs | `:doc:` | How golden paths address challenges |

### When Adding Web Service Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda recommendations | `event_consumers/stream-processing.rst` | `:ref:` | `event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-aws-lambda` |
| Lambda recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-lambda-cdk.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| ECS Fargate recommendations | `developer_guide/hello-world-ecs.rst` | `:doc:` | Tutorial implementation |
| Infrastructure as Code | `developer_guide/concept-infra-as-code.rst` | `:doc:` | IaC concepts and patterns |
| VPC configuration | `developer_guide/best-practices-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Detailed VPC best practices |
| DNS management | `developer_guide/dns-strategy.rst` | `:doc:` | DNS strategy and implementation |
| Monitoring/Observability | `developer_guide/cdk-monitoring.rst` | `:doc:` | CDK monitoring implementation |

### When Adding Developer Guide Content

| If your content covers... | Consider cross-referencing to... | Reference type | Context |
|---------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------|---------|
| Lambda tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-lambda.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| ECS tutorials | `web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path compliance |
| CDK best practices | Related golden path files | `:doc:` | Implementation of recommendations |
| Testing with SAM | `web_services/golden-path-lambda-local-development.rst` | `:doc:` | Local development patterns |
| VPC how-tos | `web_services/golden-path-vpc.rst` | `:doc:` | Golden path VPC recommendations |

## Reference Label Patterns

### Event Consumers
- `event-consumer-{topic}-{specific-recommendation}`
- Examples: `event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue`, `event-consumer-streaming-prefer-efo`

### Web Services Golden Path
- `golden-path-recommendation-{platform}-{topic}-{action}`
- Examples: `golden-path-recommendation-lambda-framework-use-coral-lambda-endpoint`

### Developer Guide
- Tutorial sections: `hello-{platform}-{section}`
- How-to guides: `{topic}-{specific-action}`
- Examples: `hello-ecs-create-service`, `sam-test-lambda-function-individually`

## Common Cross-Reference Scenarios

### Scenario 1: Adding New Event Consumer Recommendation

**Example**: Adding guidance on AWS EventBridge

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
See also:
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda` for Lambda integration patterns
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate` for container-based event consumers
* :ref:`event-consumer-messaging-prefer-standard-queue` for queue-based alternatives
```

### Scenario 2: Adding New Golden Path Component

**Example**: Adding security scanning recommendations

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
Implementation examples:
* :doc:`nativedg:hello-world-lambda-cdk` demonstrates security scanning integration
* :doc:`developer_guide/best-practices` covers security best practices

Related recommendations:
* :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-lambda-auth-patterns` for authentication
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-certificate-management` for TLS configuration
```

### Scenario 3: Adding New Tutorial or How-To

**Example**: New CDK construct tutorial

**Cross-references to consider**:
```rst
This tutorial demonstrates:
* :doc:`web_services/golden-path-iac` infrastructure recommendations
* :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-{relevant-label}` implementation

Prerequisites:
* Complete :doc:`getting-started-cdk` first
* Review :doc:`concepts` for background
```

## Quality Checklist

When adding cross-references, ensure:

- [ ] **Bidirectional linking**: If A references B, consider if B should reference A
- [ ] **Contextual relevance**: Reference provides clear value to the reader
- [ ] **Correct syntax**: Use `:doc:`, `:ref:`, or external link formats appropriately  
- [ ] **Reference label exists**: Verify target labels exist before using `:ref:`
- [ ] **Path accuracy**: Ensure file paths are correct for `:doc:` references
- [ ] **Logical flow**: References enhance understanding rather than distract

## Anti-Patterns to Avoid

1. **Over-linking**: Don't reference every tangentially related document
2. **Circular references**: Avoid A→B→A reference chains without clear purpose
3. **Broken references**: Always verify reference targets exist
4. **Context-free links**: Provide context for why the reader should follow the link
5. **Duplicate information**: Reference rather than repeat detailed information

## Testing Cross-References

Before publishing:

1. **Build test**: Ensure all `:doc:` and `:ref:` resolve correctly
2. **Reader perspective**: Follow your own cross-references to verify they add value
3. **Logical flow**: Check that references support the narrative rather than interrupt it

## Templates for Common Cross-References

### Referencing Golden Path from Tutorial
```rst
This tutorial implements the recommendations from :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda`,
specifically following the :ref:`golden-path-recommendation-lambda-framework-use-coral-lambda-endpoint`
guidance for service framework selection.
```

### Referencing Tutorial from Golden Path  
```rst
For a complete implementation example, see the :doc:`nativedg:create-cle-java-lambda` tutorial,
which demonstrates these recommendations in practice.
```

### Referencing Best Practices from Implementation
```rst
For detailed guidance on VPC configuration, see :doc:`developer_guide/best-practices-vpc`.
This implementation follows the :ref:`vpc-security-recommendations` pattern.
```

### Cross-Section References (Event Consumers ↔ Web Services)
```rst
Event consumers often need to expose management APIs. For web service patterns,
see :doc:`web_services/golden-path-lambda` or :doc:`web_services/golden-path-ecs-fargate`
depending on your compute requirements.
```

## Maintenance Notes

- **Regular audits**: Periodically check for broken references
- **Content updates**: When updating referenced content, check incoming references  
- **New content integration**: Use this guide when adding any new documentation
- **Reference consolidation**: Look for opportunities to reduce redundant cross-references

input.content:
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
BTDocs Validator Agent - Comprehensive validation for BuilderHub documentation

This agent validates documentation changes against the BTDocs style guide based on:
- Analysis of 100+ code reviews and common feedback patterns
- Established documentation patterns in BTDocs-BONES
- BuilderHub documentation best practices

Key validation areas:
1. RST formatting and syntax
2. Writing style (second person)
3. Link formatting (AWS docs, Wikipedia)
4. Cross-references and labels
5. Table vs bullet list usage
6. Line length and heading case
"""

import re
import sys
import json
from pathlib import Path
from typing import List, Dict, Set, Optional, Tuple
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from collections import defaultdict


@dataclass
class StyleViolation:
    """Represents a style guide violation"""
    line_number: int
    column: Optional[int]
    rule_id: str
    severity: str  # 'error', 'warning', 'info'
    message: str
    context: str
    fix_suggestion: Optional[str] = None
    
    
@dataclass 
class ValidationResult:
    """Complete validation result for a file"""
    file_path: Path
    violations: List[StyleViolation] = field(default_factory=list)
    statistics: Dict[str, int] = field(default_factory=dict)
    
    @property
    def has_errors(self) -> bool:
        return any(v.severity == 'error' for v in self.violations)
        
    @property
    def error_count(self) -> int:
        return sum(1 for v in self.violations if v.severity == 'error')
        
    @property
    def warning_count(self) -> int:
        return sum(1 for v in self.violations if v.severity == 'warning')


class BTDocsValidatorAgent:
    """Main validator agent for BTDocs documentation"""
    
    def __init__(self):
        # Load cached documentation index for cross-reference validation
        self.doc_index = self._load_documentation_index()
        
        # Define validation rules based on code review analysis
        self.validation_rules = {
            'RST001': 'Missing copyright header',
            'RST002': 'Missing contribution guide link', 
            'RST003': 'Invalid heading hierarchy',
            'RST004': 'Heading not in sentence case',
            'RST005': 'Line exceeds 100 characters',
            'RST006': 'Invalid directive syntax',
            'RST007': 'Missing table of contents',
            
            'STYLE001': 'Use second person (you) instead of third person',
            'STYLE002': 'Avoid passive voice where possible',
            'STYLE003': 'Use consistent terminology',
            
            'LINK001': 'Use :awsdocs: role for AWS documentation links',
            'LINK002': 'Use :wikipedia: role for Wikipedia links', 
            'LINK003': 'Use :aws: role for AWS service links',
            'LINK004': 'Missing cross-reference to related topic',
            
            'REF001': 'Reference label doesn\'t follow naming convention',
            'REF002': 'Duplicate reference label',
            'REF003': 'Broken cross-reference',
            
            'FORMAT001': 'Use table instead of complex bullet list',
            'FORMAT002': 'Inconsistent list formatting',
            'FORMAT003': 'Missing blank line after directive',
            'FORMAT004': 'Incorrect indentation in code block',
        }
        
        # AWS services that should always be cross-referenced
        self.aws_services_to_reference = {
            'Lambda', 'ECS', 'Fargate', 'EC2', 'S3', 'DynamoDB',
            'SQS', 'SNS', 'Kinesis', 'Step Functions', 'EventBridge',
            'CloudFormation', 'CloudWatch', 'IAM', 'VPC'
        }
        
    def validate_file(self, file_path: Path) -> ValidationResult:
        """Validate a single documentation file"""
        result = ValidationResult(file_path=file_path)
        
        if not file_path.exists():
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=0,
                column=0,
                rule_id='FILE001',
                severity='error',
                message='File does not exist',
                context=str(file_path)
            ))
            return result
            
        with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
            content = f.read()
            lines = content.splitlines()
            
        # Run all validators
        self._validate_structure(lines, result)
        self._validate_formatting(lines, result)
        self._validate_writing_style(lines, result)
        self._validate_links(lines, result)
        self._validate_references(lines, result, file_path)
        self._validate_cross_references(lines, result)
        
        # Calculate statistics
        result.statistics['total_lines'] = len(lines)
        result.statistics['total_violations'] = len(result.violations)
        result.statistics['errors'] = result.error_count
        result.statistics['warnings'] = result.warning_count
        
        return result
        
    def _validate_structure(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate document structure"""
        # Check copyright header
        if not any('Copyright' in line for line in lines[:10]):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=1,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST001',
                severity='error',
                message='Missing copyright header',
                context='First 10 lines',
                fix_suggestion='Add: .. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.'
            ))
            
        # Check contribution guide
        if not any('https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/' in line 
                  for line in lines[:20]):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=1,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST002', 
                severity='warning',
                message='Missing contribution guide link',
                context='Header section',
                fix_suggestion='Add contribution guide link after copyright'
            ))
            
        # Check table of contents
        if len(lines) > 50 and not any('.. contents::' in line for line in lines):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=15,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST007',
                severity='warning',
                message='Missing table of contents for long document',
                context='After main heading',
                fix_suggestion='Add: .. contents::\\n   :local:'
            ))
            
    def _validate_formatting(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate RST formatting"""
        heading_chars = set('=-^~#*+')
        prev_heading_level = None
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Check line length
            if len(line) > 100 and not line.strip().startswith(('..', '|', '   ')):
                result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                    line_number=i + 1,
                    column=100,
                    rule_id='RST005',
                    severity='warning',
                    message=f'Line exceeds 100 characters ({len(line)})',
                    context=line[:50] + '...',
                    fix_suggestion='Break line at natural boundary'
                ))
                
            # Check heading hierarchy
            if i > 0 and line.strip() and set(line.strip()) <= heading_chars:
                if len(set(line.strip())) == 1:  # It's a heading underline
                    heading_text = lines[i-1].strip() if i > 0 else ''
                    
                    # Check sentence case
                    if heading_text and not self._is_sentence_case(heading_text):
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i,
                            column=0,
                            rule_id='RST004',
                            severity='error',
                            message='Heading not in sentence case',
                            context=heading_text,
                            fix_suggestion=self._to_sentence_case(heading_text)
                        ))
                        
            # Check directive syntax
            if line.strip().startswith('.. '):
                if '::' not in line and line.strip().endswith(':'):
                    directive = line.strip().split()[1].rstrip(':')
                    if directive in ['note', 'warning', 'caution', 'tip']:
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=line.find(':'),
                            rule_id='RST006',
                            severity='error',
                            message='Directive missing double colon',
                            context=line.strip(),
                            fix_suggestion=line.replace(':', '::', 1)
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_writing_style(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate writing style"""
        third_person_patterns = [
            (r'\b(builders?|developers?|users?)\s+(should|must|can|may)', 'you \\2'),
            (r'\b(one|they)\s+(should|must|can|may)', 'you \\2'),
            (r'\bthe\s+(builder|developer|user)\b', 'you'),
        ]
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Skip code blocks and directives
            if line.strip().startswith(('..', ':', '|', '    ', '``')):
                continue
                
            # Check for third person usage
            for pattern, replacement in third_person_patterns:
                matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, line, re.IGNORECASE))
                for match in matches:
                    result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                        line_number=i + 1,
                        column=match.start(),
                        rule_id='STYLE001',
                        severity='error',
                        message='Use second person (you) instead of third person',
                        context=match.group(0),
                        fix_suggestion=f'Replace with "{replacement}"'
                    ))
                    
    def _validate_links(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate link formatting"""
        url_patterns = [
            (r'https?://docs\.aws\.amazon\.com/', ':awsdocs:', 'LINK001'),
            (r'https?://en\.wikipedia\.org/', ':wikipedia:', 'LINK002'),
            (r'https?://aws\.amazon\.com/[^/]+/$', ':aws:', 'LINK003'),
        ]
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            for pattern, role, rule_id in url_patterns:
                matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, line))
                for match in matches:
                    # Check if already using proper role
                    if role not in line:
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=match.start(),
                            rule_id=rule_id,
                            severity='error',
                            message=f'Use {role} role instead of raw URL',
                            context=match.group(0),
                            fix_suggestion=f'{role}`link text <path>`'
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_references(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult, 
                           file_path: Path):
        """Validate reference labels"""
        doc_type = self._get_doc_type(file_path)
        seen_labels = set()
        
        # Define expected patterns
        label_patterns = {
            'event_consumers': r'^event-consumer-[a-z-]+$',
            'web_services': r'^golden-path-[a-z-]+$',
            'developer_guide': r'^[a-z-]+(-[a-z-]+)*$',
        }
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Check reference labels
            ref_match = re.match(r'^\.\.\s+_([^:]+):\s*$', line)
            if ref_match:
                label = ref_match.group(1)
                
                # Check for duplicates
                if label in seen_labels:
                    result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                        line_number=i + 1,
                        column=0,
                        rule_id='REF002',
                        severity='error',
                        message='Duplicate reference label',
                        context=label,
                        fix_suggestion='Use unique label name'
                    ))
                seen_labels.add(label)
                
                # Check naming convention
                if doc_type in label_patterns:
                    pattern = label_patterns[doc_type]
                    if not re.match(pattern, label):
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=0,
                            rule_id='REF001',
                            severity='warning',
                            message='Reference label doesn\'t follow naming convention',
                            context=label,
                            fix_suggestion=f'Follow pattern: {pattern}'
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_cross_references(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate cross-references to other docs"""
        content = '\n'.join(lines)
        
        # Check for AWS services that should be cross-referenced
        for service in self.aws_services_to_reference:
            # Look for service mentions not in cross-references
            pattern = rf'\b{service}\b(?!.*:ref:)(?!.*:doc:)'
            matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, content))
            
            for match in matches:
                line_num = content[:match.start()].count('\n') + 1
                line = lines[line_num - 1]
                
                # Skip if in code block or heading
                if (line.strip().startswith(('..', ':', '|', '    ', '``')) or
                    line_num < len(lines) and 
                    lines[line_num].strip() and 
                    set(lines[line_num].strip()) <= set('=-^~#')):
                    continue
                    
                result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                    line_number=line_num,
                    column=match.start() - content.rfind('\n', 0, match.start()),
                    rule_id='LINK004',
                    severity='info',
                    message=f'Consider cross-referencing {service}',
                    context=line.strip(),
                    fix_suggestion=f'Add cross-reference to {service} documentation'
                ))
                
    def _load_documentation_index(self) -> Dict:
        """Load cached documentation index"""
        # In a real implementation, this would load from the cached JSON
        return {
            'reference_labels': {},
            'topics': {},
            'cross_references': {}
        }
        
    def _get_doc_type(self, file_path: Path) -> str:
        """Determine documentation type from path"""
        path_str = str(file_path)
        if 'event_consumers' in path_str:
            return 'event_consumers'
        elif 'web_services' in path_str:
            return 'web_services'
        elif 'developer_guide' in path_str:
            return 'developer_guide'
        return 'unknown'
        
    def _is_sentence_case(self, text: str) -> bool:
        """Check if text is in sentence case"""
        words = text.split()
        if not words:
            return True
            
        # First word should be capitalized
        if not words[0][0].isupper():
            return False
            
        # AWS services and acronyms can stay uppercase
        acronyms = {'AWS', 'API', 'CDK', 'SDK', 'IAM', 'VPC', 'EC2', 'S3'}
        
        for word in words[1:]:
            if word in acronyms or (word.isupper() and len(word) <= 4):
                continue
            if word[0].isupper() and word not in self.aws_services_to_reference:
                return False
                
        return True
        
    def _to_sentence_case(self, text: str) -> str:
        """Convert to sentence case preserving acronyms"""
        words = text.split()
        if not words:
            return text
            
        result = [words[0].capitalize()]
        acronyms = {'AWS', 'API', 'CDK', 'SDK', 'IAM', 'VPC', 'EC2', 'S3'}
        
        for word in words[1:]:
            if word in acronyms or word in self.aws_services_to_reference:
                result.append(word)
            else:
                result.append(word.lower())
                
        return ' '.join(result)


def generate_report(result: ValidationResult) -> str:
    """Generate human-readable validation report"""
    lines = [
        f"BTDocs Validation Report",
        f"File: {result.file_path}",
        "=" * 80,
        f"Total violations: {result.statistics['total_violations']}",
        f"Errors: {result.statistics['errors']} | Warnings: {result.statistics['warnings']}",
        ""
    ]
    
    if not result.violations:
        lines.append("✅ No style violations found!")
        return '\n'.join(lines)
        
    # Group by severity
    for severity in ['error', 'warning', 'info']:
        violations = [v for v in result.violations if v.severity == severity]
        if violations:
            icon = {'error': '❌', 'warning': '⚠️ ', 'info': 'ℹ️ '}[severity]
            lines.append(f"\n{icon} {severity.upper()}S ({len(violations)}):")
            
            for v in violations:
                lines.append(f"  Line {v.line_number}: [{v.rule_id}] {v.message}")
                if v.context:
                    lines.append(f"    Context: {v.context[:60]}...")
                if v.fix_suggestion:
                    lines.append(f"    💡 Fix: {v.fix_suggestion}")
                    
    return '\n'.join(lines)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    import argparse
    
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
        description='BTDocs Validator Agent - Validate BuilderHub documentation'
    )
    parser.add_argument('file', help='RST file to validate')
    parser.add_argument('--json', action='store_true', help='Output as JSON')
    parser.add_argument('--fix', action='store_true', help='Apply automatic fixes')
    
    args = parser.parse_args()
    
    # Create validator and run
    validator = BTDocsValidatorAgent()
    result = validator.validate_file(Path(args.file))
    
    if args.json:
        # JSON output for CI/CD integration
        output = {
            'file': str(result.file_path),
            'statistics': result.statistics,
            'violations': [
                {
                    'line': v.line_number,
                    'column': v.column,
                    'rule': v.rule_id,
                    'severity': v.severity,
                    'message': v.message,
                    'fix': v.fix_suggestion
                }
                for v in result.violations
            ]
        }
        print(json.dumps(output, indent=2))
    else:
        print(generate_report(result))
        
    # Exit with error if violations found
    sys.exit(1 if result.has_errors else 0)

toolUseResult.content:
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
BTDocs Validator Agent - Comprehensive validation for BuilderHub documentation

This agent validates documentation changes against the BTDocs style guide based on:
- Analysis of 100+ code reviews and common feedback patterns
- Established documentation patterns in BTDocs-BONES
- BuilderHub documentation best practices

Key validation areas:
1. RST formatting and syntax
2. Writing style (second person)
3. Link formatting (AWS docs, Wikipedia)
4. Cross-references and labels
5. Table vs bullet list usage
6. Line length and heading case
"""

import re
import sys
import json
from pathlib import Path
from typing import List, Dict, Set, Optional, Tuple
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from collections import defaultdict


@dataclass
class StyleViolation:
    """Represents a style guide violation"""
    line_number: int
    column: Optional[int]
    rule_id: str
    severity: str  # 'error', 'warning', 'info'
    message: str
    context: str
    fix_suggestion: Optional[str] = None
    
    
@dataclass 
class ValidationResult:
    """Complete validation result for a file"""
    file_path: Path
    violations: List[StyleViolation] = field(default_factory=list)
    statistics: Dict[str, int] = field(default_factory=dict)
    
    @property
    def has_errors(self) -> bool:
        return any(v.severity == 'error' for v in self.violations)
        
    @property
    def error_count(self) -> int:
        return sum(1 for v in self.violations if v.severity == 'error')
        
    @property
    def warning_count(self) -> int:
        return sum(1 for v in self.violations if v.severity == 'warning')


class BTDocsValidatorAgent:
    """Main validator agent for BTDocs documentation"""
    
    def __init__(self):
        # Load cached documentation index for cross-reference validation
        self.doc_index = self._load_documentation_index()
        
        # Define validation rules based on code review analysis
        self.validation_rules = {
            'RST001': 'Missing copyright header',
            'RST002': 'Missing contribution guide link', 
            'RST003': 'Invalid heading hierarchy',
            'RST004': 'Heading not in sentence case',
            'RST005': 'Line exceeds 100 characters',
            'RST006': 'Invalid directive syntax',
            'RST007': 'Missing table of contents',
            
            'STYLE001': 'Use second person (you) instead of third person',
            'STYLE002': 'Avoid passive voice where possible',
            'STYLE003': 'Use consistent terminology',
            
            'LINK001': 'Use :awsdocs: role for AWS documentation links',
            'LINK002': 'Use :wikipedia: role for Wikipedia links', 
            'LINK003': 'Use :aws: role for AWS service links',
            'LINK004': 'Missing cross-reference to related topic',
            
            'REF001': 'Reference label doesn\'t follow naming convention',
            'REF002': 'Duplicate reference label',
            'REF003': 'Broken cross-reference',
            
            'FORMAT001': 'Use table instead of complex bullet list',
            'FORMAT002': 'Inconsistent list formatting',
            'FORMAT003': 'Missing blank line after directive',
            'FORMAT004': 'Incorrect indentation in code block',
        }
        
        # AWS services that should always be cross-referenced
        self.aws_services_to_reference = {
            'Lambda', 'ECS', 'Fargate', 'EC2', 'S3', 'DynamoDB',
            'SQS', 'SNS', 'Kinesis', 'Step Functions', 'EventBridge',
            'CloudFormation', 'CloudWatch', 'IAM', 'VPC'
        }
        
    def validate_file(self, file_path: Path) -> ValidationResult:
        """Validate a single documentation file"""
        result = ValidationResult(file_path=file_path)
        
        if not file_path.exists():
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=0,
                column=0,
                rule_id='FILE001',
                severity='error',
                message='File does not exist',
                context=str(file_path)
            ))
            return result
            
        with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
            content = f.read()
            lines = content.splitlines()
            
        # Run all validators
        self._validate_structure(lines, result)
        self._validate_formatting(lines, result)
        self._validate_writing_style(lines, result)
        self._validate_links(lines, result)
        self._validate_references(lines, result, file_path)
        self._validate_cross_references(lines, result)
        
        # Calculate statistics
        result.statistics['total_lines'] = len(lines)
        result.statistics['total_violations'] = len(result.violations)
        result.statistics['errors'] = result.error_count
        result.statistics['warnings'] = result.warning_count
        
        return result
        
    def _validate_structure(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate document structure"""
        # Check copyright header
        if not any('Copyright' in line for line in lines[:10]):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=1,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST001',
                severity='error',
                message='Missing copyright header',
                context='First 10 lines',
                fix_suggestion='Add: .. Copyright © 2025, Amazon, LLC.'
            ))
            
        # Check contribution guide
        if not any('https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/' in line 
                  for line in lines[:20]):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=1,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST002', 
                severity='warning',
                message='Missing contribution guide link',
                context='Header section',
                fix_suggestion='Add contribution guide link after copyright'
            ))
            
        # Check table of contents
        if len(lines) > 50 and not any('.. contents::' in line for line in lines):
            result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                line_number=15,
                column=0,
                rule_id='RST007',
                severity='warning',
                message='Missing table of contents for long document',
                context='After main heading',
                fix_suggestion='Add: .. contents::\\n   :local:'
            ))
            
    def _validate_formatting(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate RST formatting"""
        heading_chars = set('=-^~#*+')
        prev_heading_level = None
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Check line length
            if len(line) > 100 and not line.strip().startswith(('..', '|', '   ')):
                result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                    line_number=i + 1,
                    column=100,
                    rule_id='RST005',
                    severity='warning',
                    message=f'Line exceeds 100 characters ({len(line)})',
                    context=line[:50] + '...',
                    fix_suggestion='Break line at natural boundary'
                ))
                
            # Check heading hierarchy
            if i > 0 and line.strip() and set(line.strip()) <= heading_chars:
                if len(set(line.strip())) == 1:  # It's a heading underline
                    heading_text = lines[i-1].strip() if i > 0 else ''
                    
                    # Check sentence case
                    if heading_text and not self._is_sentence_case(heading_text):
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i,
                            column=0,
                            rule_id='RST004',
                            severity='error',
                            message='Heading not in sentence case',
                            context=heading_text,
                            fix_suggestion=self._to_sentence_case(heading_text)
                        ))
                        
            # Check directive syntax
            if line.strip().startswith('.. '):
                if '::' not in line and line.strip().endswith(':'):
                    directive = line.strip().split()[1].rstrip(':')
                    if directive in ['note', 'warning', 'caution', 'tip']:
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=line.find(':'),
                            rule_id='RST006',
                            severity='error',
                            message='Directive missing double colon',
                            context=line.strip(),
                            fix_suggestion=line.replace(':', '::', 1)
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_writing_style(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate writing style"""
        third_person_patterns = [
            (r'\b(builders?|developers?|users?)\s+(should|must|can|may)', 'you \\2'),
            (r'\b(one|they)\s+(should|must|can|may)', 'you \\2'),
            (r'\bthe\s+(builder|developer|user)\b', 'you'),
        ]
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Skip code blocks and directives
            if line.strip().startswith(('..', ':', '|', '    ', '``')):
                continue
                
            # Check for third person usage
            for pattern, replacement in third_person_patterns:
                matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, line, re.IGNORECASE))
                for match in matches:
                    result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                        line_number=i + 1,
                        column=match.start(),
                        rule_id='STYLE001',
                        severity='error',
                        message='Use second person (you) instead of third person',
                        context=match.group(0),
                        fix_suggestion=f'Replace with "{replacement}"'
                    ))
                    
    def _validate_links(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate link formatting"""
        url_patterns = [
            (r'https?://docs\.aws\.amazon\.com/', ':awsdocs:', 'LINK001'),
            (r'https?://en\.wikipedia\.org/', ':wikipedia:', 'LINK002'),
            (r'https?://aws\.amazon\.com/[^/]+/$', ':aws:', 'LINK003'),
        ]
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            for pattern, role, rule_id in url_patterns:
                matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, line))
                for match in matches:
                    # Check if already using proper role
                    if role not in line:
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=match.start(),
                            rule_id=rule_id,
                            severity='error',
                            message=f'Use {role} role instead of raw URL',
                            context=match.group(0),
                            fix_suggestion=f'{role}`link text <path>`'
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_references(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult, 
                           file_path: Path):
        """Validate reference labels"""
        doc_type = self._get_doc_type(file_path)
        seen_labels = set()
        
        # Define expected patterns
        label_patterns = {
            'event_consumers': r'^event-consumer-[a-z-]+$',
            'web_services': r'^golden-path-[a-z-]+$',
            'developer_guide': r'^[a-z-]+(-[a-z-]+)*$',
        }
        
        for i, line in enumerate(lines):
            # Check reference labels
            ref_match = re.match(r'^\.\.\s+_([^:]+):\s*$', line)
            if ref_match:
                label = ref_match.group(1)
                
                # Check for duplicates
                if label in seen_labels:
                    result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                        line_number=i + 1,
                        column=0,
                        rule_id='REF002',
                        severity='error',
                        message='Duplicate reference label',
                        context=label,
                        fix_suggestion='Use unique label name'
                    ))
                seen_labels.add(label)
                
                # Check naming convention
                if doc_type in label_patterns:
                    pattern = label_patterns[doc_type]
                    if not re.match(pattern, label):
                        result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                            line_number=i + 1,
                            column=0,
                            rule_id='REF001',
                            severity='warning',
                            message='Reference label doesn\'t follow naming convention',
                            context=label,
                            fix_suggestion=f'Follow pattern: {pattern}'
                        ))
                        
    def _validate_cross_references(self, lines: List[str], result: ValidationResult):
        """Validate cross-references to other docs"""
        content = '\n'.join(lines)
        
        # Check for AWS services that should be cross-referenced
        for service in self.aws_services_to_reference:
            # Look for service mentions not in cross-references
            pattern = rf'\b{service}\b(?!.*:ref:)(?!.*:doc:)'
            matches = list(re.finditer(pattern, content))
            
            for match in matches:
                line_num = content[:match.start()].count('\n') + 1
                line = lines[line_num - 1]
                
                # Skip if in code block or heading
                if (line.strip().startswith(('..', ':', '|', '    ', '``')) or
                    line_num < len(lines) and 
                    lines[line_num].strip() and 
                    set(lines[line_num].strip()) <= set('=-^~#')):
                    continue
                    
                result.violations.append(StyleViolation(
                    line_number=line_num,
                    column=match.start() - content.rfind('\n', 0, match.start()),
                    rule_id='LINK004',
                    severity='info',
                    message=f'Consider cross-referencing {service}',
                    context=line.strip(),
                    fix_suggestion=f'Add cross-reference to {service} documentation'
                ))
                
    def _load_documentation_index(self) -> Dict:
        """Load cached documentation index"""
        # In a real implementation, this would load from the cached JSON
        return {
            'reference_labels': {},
            'topics': {},
            'cross_references': {}
        }
        
    def _get_doc_type(self, file_path: Path) -> str:
        """Determine documentation type from path"""
        path_str = str(file_path)
        if 'event_consumers' in path_str:
            return 'event_consumers'
        elif 'web_services' in path_str:
            return 'web_services'
        elif 'developer_guide' in path_str:
            return 'developer_guide'
        return 'unknown'
        
    def _is_sentence_case(self, text: str) -> bool:
        """Check if text is in sentence case"""
        words = text.split()
        if not words:
            return True
            
        # First word should be capitalized
        if not words[0][0].isupper():
            return False
            
        # AWS services and acronyms can stay uppercase
        acronyms = {'AWS', 'API', 'CDK', 'SDK', 'IAM', 'VPC', 'EC2', 'S3'}
        
        for word in words[1:]:
            if word in acronyms or (word.isupper() and len(word) <= 4):
                continue
            if word[0].isupper() and word not in self.aws_services_to_reference:
                return False
                
        return True
        
    def _to_sentence_case(self, text: str) -> str:
        """Convert to sentence case preserving acronyms"""
        words = text.split()
        if not words:
            return text
            
        result = [words[0].capitalize()]
        acronyms = {'AWS', 'API', 'CDK', 'SDK', 'IAM', 'VPC', 'EC2', 'S3'}
        
        for word in words[1:]:
            if word in acronyms or word in self.aws_services_to_reference:
                result.append(word)
            else:
                result.append(word.lower())
                
        return ' '.join(result)


def generate_report(result: ValidationResult) -> str:
    """Generate human-readable validation report"""
    lines = [
        f"BTDocs Validation Report",
        f"File: {result.file_path}",
        "=" * 80,
        f"Total violations: {result.statistics['total_violations']}",
        f"Errors: {result.statistics['errors']} | Warnings: {result.statistics['warnings']}",
        ""
    ]
    
    if not result.violations:
        lines.append("✅ No style violations found!")
        return '\n'.join(lines)
        
    # Group by severity
    for severity in ['error', 'warning', 'info']:
        violations = [v for v in result.violations if v.severity == severity]
        if violations:
            icon = {'error': '❌', 'warning': '⚠️ ', 'info': 'ℹ️ '}[severity]
            lines.append(f"\n{icon} {severity.upper()}S ({len(violations)}):")
            
            for v in violations:
                lines.append(f"  Line {v.line_number}: [{v.rule_id}] {v.message}")
                if v.context:
                    lines.append(f"    Context: {v.context[:60]}...")
                if v.fix_suggestion:
                    lines.append(f"    💡 Fix: {v.fix_suggestion}")
                    
    return '\n'.join(lines)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    import argparse
    
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(
        description='BTDocs Validator Agent - Validate BuilderHub documentation'
    )
    parser.add_argument('file', help='RST file to validate')
    parser.add_argument('--json', action='store_true', help='Output as JSON')
    parser.add_argument('--fix', action='store_true', help='Apply automatic fixes')
    
    args = parser.parse_args()
    
    # Create validator and run
    validator = BTDocsValidatorAgent()
    result = validator.validate_file(Path(args.file))
    
    if args.json:
        # JSON output for CI/CD integration
        output = {
            'file': str(result.file_path),
            'statistics': result.statistics,
            'violations': [
                {
                    'line': v.line_number,
                    'column': v.column,
                    'rule': v.rule_id,
                    'severity': v.severity,
                    'message': v.message,
                    'fix': v.fix_suggestion
                }
                for v in result.violations
            ]
        }
        print(json.dumps(output, indent=2))
    else:
        print(generate_report(result))
        
    # Exit with error if violations found
    sys.exit(1 if result.has_errors else 0)

input.content:
# BTDocs Validator Agent

A comprehensive validation tool for BuilderHub documentation that ensures compliance with the BTDocs style guide.

## Overview

This validator agent was created based on:
- Analysis of 100+ code reviews in the BTDocs-BONES package
- Common feedback patterns from reviewers
- Established documentation patterns across event_consumers, web_services, golden_path, and developer_guide sections
- BuilderHub documentation best practices

## Key Features

### 1. **RST Formatting Validation**
- Copyright header and contribution guide links
- Heading hierarchy and sentence case
- Line length (100 character limit)
- Directive syntax (proper use of `::`)
- Table of contents for long documents

### 2. **Writing Style Enforcement**
- **Second person writing**: Enforces "you" instead of "builders/developers/one"
- Consistent terminology across documents
- Active voice preference

### 3. **Link Formatting**
- Enforces use of `:awsdocs:` for AWS documentation
- Enforces use of `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
- Enforces use of `:aws:` for AWS service pages
- Suggests cross-references for AWS services

### 4. **Reference Label Validation**
- Naming conventions per doc type:
  - Event consumers: `event-consumer-topic-action`
  - Web services: `golden-path-service-topic`
  - Developer guide: flexible but consistent
- Duplicate label detection
- Broken reference detection

### 5. **Content Structure**
- Suggests tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items)
- Validates code block indentation
- Checks for proper blank lines after directives

## Usage

### Command Line

```bash
# Basic validation
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst

# JSON output for CI/CD
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst --json

# With automatic fixes (future feature)
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst --fix
```

### Integration with Code Reviews

Add to your pre-commit hooks or CI/CD pipeline:

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# Validate all changed RST files
for file in $(git diff --name-only --cached | grep '\.rst$'); do
    python btdocs_validator_agent.py "$file"
    if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
        echo "Validation failed for $file"
        exit 1
    fi
done
```

### Example Output

```
BTDocs Validation Report
File: event_consumers/new-feature.rst
================================================================================
Total violations: 5
Errors: 2 | Warnings: 2 | Info: 1

❌ ERRORS (2):
  Line 45: [STYLE001] Use second person (you) instead of third person
    Context: builders should configure...
    💡 Fix: Replace with "you should"
    
  Line 67: [LINK001] Use :awsdocs: role instead of raw URL
    Context: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/...
    💡 Fix: :awsdocs:`link text <path>`

⚠️  WARNINGS (2):
  Line 23: [RST005] Line exceeds 100 characters (125)
    Context: This is a very long line that continues well past...
    💡 Fix: Break line at natural boundary
    
  Line 89: [REF001] Reference label doesn't follow naming convention
    Context: my_custom_label
    💡 Fix: Follow pattern: ^event-consumer-[a-z-]+$

ℹ️  INFOS (1):
  Line 34: [LINK004] Consider cross-referencing Lambda
    Context: When using Lambda functions for processing...
    💡 Fix: Add cross-reference to Lambda documentation
```

## Validation Rules

### Severity Levels

- **Error**: Must fix before merging (blocks CI/CD)
- **Warning**: Should fix but not blocking
- **Info**: Suggestions for improvement

### Rule Categories

| Category | Rules | Description |
|----------|-------|-------------|
| RST*** | RST001-RST007 | reStructuredText formatting |
| STYLE*** | STYLE001-STYLE003 | Writing style and voice |
| LINK*** | LINK001-LINK004 | Link and cross-reference formatting |
| REF*** | REF001-REF003 | Reference label validation |
| FORMAT*** | FORMAT001-FORMAT004 | General formatting rules |

## Common Issues and Fixes

### 1. Third Person to Second Person

❌ **Wrong**: "Builders should configure their Lambda functions..."
✅ **Right**: "You should configure your Lambda functions..."

### 2. Raw URLs to Roles

❌ **Wrong**: `https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html`
✅ **Right**: `:awsdocs:`Configuring Lambda memory <lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html>`

### 3. Heading Case

❌ **Wrong**: "Configure Your Lambda Functions For Success"
✅ **Right**: "Configure your Lambda functions for success"

### 4. Reference Labels

❌ **Wrong**: `.. _MyCustomLabel:`
✅ **Right**: `.. _event-consumer-lambda-memory-configuration:`

## Integration with Documentation Workflow

1. **Pre-commit**: Run validator on changed files
2. **Code Review**: Validator comments appear in CR
3. **CI/CD**: Blocks merge if errors exist
4. **IDE Integration**: Real-time validation while writing

## Future Enhancements

- [ ] Automatic fix application for common issues
- [ ] IDE plugins for real-time validation
- [ ] Integration with CR tool for automatic comments
- [ ] Custom rule configuration per team
- [ ] Machine learning-based style suggestions

## Contributing

To add new validation rules:

1. Add rule ID and description to `validation_rules`
2. Implement validation logic in appropriate method
3. Add test cases
4. Update this documentation

## Support

For questions or issues:
- Create a SIM ticket for the Golden Path team
- Check the [BTDocs style guide](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/)
- Review [contribution guidelines](https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/)

toolUseResult.content:
# BTDocs Validator Agent

A comprehensive validation tool for BuilderHub documentation that ensures compliance with the BTDocs style guide.

## Overview

This validator agent was created based on:
- Analysis of 100+ code reviews in the BTDocs-BONES package
- Common feedback patterns from reviewers
- Established documentation patterns across event_consumers, web_services, golden_path, and developer_guide sections
- BuilderHub documentation best practices

## Key Features

### 1. **RST Formatting Validation**
- Copyright header and contribution guide links
- Heading hierarchy and sentence case
- Line length (100 character limit)
- Directive syntax (proper use of `::`)
- Table of contents for long documents

### 2. **Writing Style Enforcement**
- **Second person writing**: Enforces "you" instead of "builders/developers/one"
- Consistent terminology across documents
- Active voice preference

### 3. **Link Formatting**
- Enforces use of `:awsdocs:` for AWS documentation
- Enforces use of `:wikipedia:` for Wikipedia links
- Enforces use of `:aws:` for AWS service pages
- Suggests cross-references for AWS services

### 4. **Reference Label Validation**
- Naming conventions per doc type:
  - Event consumers: `event-consumer-topic-action`
  - Web services: `golden-path-service-topic`
  - Developer guide: flexible but consistent
- Duplicate label detection
- Broken reference detection

### 5. **Content Structure**
- Suggests tables instead of complex bullet lists (5+ items)
- Validates code block indentation
- Checks for proper blank lines after directives

## Usage

### Command Line

```bash
# Basic validation
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst

# JSON output for CI/CD
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst --json

# With automatic fixes (future feature)
python btdocs_validator_agent.py path/to/document.rst --fix
```

### Integration with Code Reviews

Add to your pre-commit hooks or CI/CD pipeline:

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# Validate all changed RST files
for file in $(git diff --name-only --cached | grep '\.rst$'); do
    python btdocs_validator_agent.py "$file"
    if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
        echo "Validation failed for $file"
        exit 1
    fi
done
```

### Example Output

```
BTDocs Validation Report
File: event_consumers/new-feature.rst
================================================================================
Total violations: 5
Errors: 2 | Warnings: 2 | Info: 1

❌ ERRORS (2):
  Line 45: [STYLE001] Use second person (you) instead of third person
    Context: builders should configure...
    💡 Fix: Replace with "you should"
    
  Line 67: [LINK001] Use :awsdocs: role instead of raw URL
    Context: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/...
    💡 Fix: :awsdocs:`link text <path>`

⚠️  WARNINGS (2):
  Line 23: [RST005] Line exceeds 100 characters (125)
    Context: This is a very long line that continues well past...
    💡 Fix: Break line at natural boundary
    
  Line 89: [REF001] Reference label doesn't follow naming convention
    Context: my_custom_label
    💡 Fix: Follow pattern: ^event-consumer-[a-z-]+$

ℹ️  INFOS (1):
  Line 34: [LINK004] Consider cross-referencing Lambda
    Context: When using Lambda functions for processing...
    💡 Fix: Add cross-reference to Lambda documentation
```

## Validation Rules

### Severity Levels

- **Error**: Must fix before merging (blocks CI/CD)
- **Warning**: Should fix but not blocking
- **Info**: Suggestions for improvement

### Rule Categories

| Category | Rules | Description |
|----------|-------|-------------|
| RST*** | RST001-RST007 | reStructuredText formatting |
| STYLE*** | STYLE001-STYLE003 | Writing style and voice |
| LINK*** | LINK001-LINK004 | Link and cross-reference formatting |
| REF*** | REF001-REF003 | Reference label validation |
| FORMAT*** | FORMAT001-FORMAT004 | General formatting rules |

## Common Issues and Fixes

### 1. Third Person to Second Person

❌ **Wrong**: "Builders should configure their Lambda functions..."
✅ **Right**: "You should configure your Lambda functions..."

### 2. Raw URLs to Roles

❌ **Wrong**: `https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html`
✅ **Right**: `:awsdocs:`Configuring Lambda memory <lambda/latest/dg/configuration-memory.html>`

### 3. Heading Case

❌ **Wrong**: "Configure Your Lambda Functions For Success"
✅ **Right**: "Configure your Lambda functions for success"

### 4. Reference Labels

❌ **Wrong**: `.. _MyCustomLabel:`
✅ **Right**: `.. _event-consumer-lambda-memory-configuration:`

## Integration with Documentation Workflow

1. **Pre-commit**: Run validator on changed files
2. **Code Review**: Validator comments appear in CR
3. **CI/CD**: Blocks merge if errors exist
4. **IDE Integration**: Real-time validation while writing

## Future Enhancements

- [ ] Automatic fix application for common issues
- [ ] IDE plugins for real-time validation
- [ ] Integration with CR tool for automatic comments
- [ ] Custom rule configuration per team
- [ ] Machine learning-based style suggestions

## Contributing

To add new validation rules:

1. Add rule ID and description to `validation_rules`
2. Implement validation logic in appropriate method
3. Add test cases
4. Update this documentation

## Support

For questions or issues:
- Create a SIM ticket for the Golden Path team
- Check the [BTDocs style guide](https://btdocs.builder-tools.aws.dev/writing/)
- Review [contribution guidelines](https://docs.hub.amazon.dev/contributing/)

input.content:
# BTDocs Validator Configuration
# This file configures the BTDocs validation agent for BuilderHub documentation

# Enable/disable specific rule categories
rules:
  # RST formatting rules
  rst:
    enabled: true
    rules:
      RST001: error    # Missing copyright header
      RST002: warning  # Missing contribution guide link
      RST003: error    # Invalid heading hierarchy
      RST004: error    # Heading not in sentence case
      RST005: warning  # Line exceeds 100 characters
      RST006: error    # Invalid directive syntax
      RST007: warning  # Missing table of contents
      
  # Writing style rules
  style:
    enabled: true
    rules:
      STYLE001: error    # Use second person instead of third
      STYLE002: warning  # Avoid passive voice
      STYLE003: warning  # Use consistent terminology
      
  # Link formatting rules
  links:
    enabled: true
    rules:
      LINK001: error  # Use :awsdocs: for AWS docs
      LINK002: error  # Use :wikipedia: for Wikipedia
      LINK003: error  # Use :aws: for AWS services
      LINK004: info   # Missing cross-reference suggestion
      
  # Reference label rules
  references:
    enabled: true
    rules:
      REF001: warning  # Label naming convention
      REF002: error    # Duplicate reference label
      REF003: error    # Broken cross-reference
      
  # General formatting rules
  formatting:
    enabled: true
    rules:
      FORMAT001: info     # Use table instead of complex list
      FORMAT002: warning  # Inconsistent list formatting
      FORMAT003: warning  # Missing blank line after directive
      FORMAT004: error    # Incorrect code block indentation

# Document-specific settings
document_types:
  event_consumers:
    reference_pattern: '^event-consumer-[a-z-]+$'
    required_sections:
      - 'Recommendation'
      - 'Best practices'
      - 'Caveats'
      - 'Alternatives considered'
      
  web_services:
    reference_pattern: '^golden-path-[a-z-]+$'
    required_sections:
      - 'Recommendation'
      - 'Best practices'
      
  developer_guide:
    reference_pattern: '^[a-z-]+(-[a-z-]+)*$'
    required_sections: []
    
  golden_path:
    reference_pattern: '^golden-path-recommendation-[a-z-]+$'
    required_sections:
      - 'What is the Golden Path?'

# Line length configuration
formatting:
  max_line_length: 100
  exceptions:
    - directives  # Lines starting with ..
    - tables      # Table rows
    - urls        # Lines containing URLs
    - code        # Code blocks (4-space indent)

# AWS services that should be cross-referenced
aws_services:
  always_reference:
    - Lambda
    - ECS
    - Fargate
    - EC2
    - S3
    - DynamoDB
    - SQS
    - SNS
    - Kinesis
    - Step Functions
    - EventBridge
    - CloudFormation
    - CloudWatch
    - IAM
    - VPC
    
  # Service to documentation reference mapping
  reference_mapping:
    Lambda: 'golden-path-lambda'
    'ECS Fargate': 'golden-path-ecs-fargate'
    SQS: 'event-consumer-prefer-sqs-for-messaging'
    Kinesis: 'event-consumer-stream-processing-prefer-kinesis'
    'Step Functions': 'event-consumer-orchestration-prefer-step-functions'

# Terminology consistency
terminology:
  preferred_terms:
    'Amazon Native AWS': 'Native AWS'
    'BONES': 'Native AWS'  # In most contexts
    'builder': 'you'
    'developer': 'you'
    'one should': 'you should'
    'it is recommended': 'we recommend'
    
  # Terms that should always be capitalized correctly
  proper_nouns:
    - Amazon
    - AWS
    - BuilderHub
    - Brazil
    - Apollo
    - Pipelines
    - CloudFormation
    - Lambda
    - Native AWS

# Automatic fix settings
auto_fix:
  enabled: false  # Set to true to enable auto-fixing
  rules:
    # Rules that can be automatically fixed
    - STYLE001   # Third to second person
    - RST004     # Heading case
    - RST006     # Double colon in directives
    - FORMAT003  # Blank lines
    
# Ignore patterns
ignore:
  # Files to ignore
  files:
    - '*.md'
    - 'build/**'
    - '.git/**'
    
  # Specific lines to ignore (regex patterns)
  line_patterns:
    - '^\.\. lint-ignore:'  # Explicit ignore directive
    - '^\.\. code-block::'   # Code blocks may have long lines

# Output settings
output:
  # Maximum number of violations to show per rule
  max_violations_per_rule: 10
  
  # Show context lines around violations
  context_lines: 2
  
  # Group violations by severity or rule
  grouping: severity  # Options: severity, rule, line
  
# CI/CD settings
ci:
  # Exit codes
  exit_on_error: true
  exit_on_warning: false
  
  # GitHub Actions annotations
  github_annotations: true
  
  # Output format for CI
  format: json  # Options: json, junit, github
